TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, is returning today from an official visit overseas and will be absent from Question Time. Questions normally directed to Senator Ray should be directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In order that the very useful experiment on restraining Ministers during Question Time might continue, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to provide for a time limit on questions and answers during Question Time in the weeks beginning 6 October and 12 October 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand the Government will agree to that; so I will not debate it.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Hill) proposed:

That a motion to provide for a time limit on questions and answers during Question Time in the weeks beginning 6 October and 12 October 1992 may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business until determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate really deserves a little more explanation than has been given on this motion. This is the first knowledge that I have had of an intention to move such a motion. If the intention is simply to enable a motion to be moved at any time to limit questions and to limit answers and that, by voting for such a motion, we are not in fact agreeing to that proposition, then I have no quarrel with it. But presumably, now that I have risen to my feet, it will enable the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) to explain the motion a little more for us, if he would not mind.
—As far as I am aware, we will put that formal motion and then Senator Hill will move the substantive motion. Debate can then proceed on the substantive motion.
—Mr Deputy President, I misunderstand. I thought a motion was carried for the suspension of Standing Orders for Senator Hill to move a motion. Was that not so?
—That is correct, but Senator Hill then had to move a procedural motion, which he has just moved. If that is passed, we will then have the substantive motion. So I put that motion.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That during Question Time in the weeks commencing 6 October and 12 October 1992:
(a) the asking of each question not exceed one minute and the answering of each question not exceed two minutes;
(b) the asking of each supplementary question not exceed one minute and the answering of each supplementary question not exceed two minutes;
(c) the time taken to determine the suspension of Standing Orders and this motion not be regarded as part of the time for questions today; and
(d) the time taken to make and determine points of order not be regarded as part of the time for questions and answers.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, as you will recall, the Senate found it necessary when we were last sitting to restrict Ministers in their answering of questions. That was not a procedure that we entered into without due consideration. The Senate had suffered constant abuse by Ministers of Question Time in that they had completely avoided their responsibility of answering questions and accounting for the administration of their portfolios. Rather they saw Question Time simply as an opportunity to get up and abuse the Opposition and the Opposition's program under the protection of the Chair for as long as they liked.It was necessary in those circumstances to take some action to restrict them to try to bring this abuse to an end.

PARA.TAB: We were aware, of course, that they had taken their instructions in this matter from the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and the way that he and his people behaved in the other place, where they see the whole of Question Time simply as an opportunity to bucket the Opposition rather than to accept any responsibility to account whatsoever. This place did not have that tradition. In this place Ministers traditionally made an attempt to answer questions and to account for their performance. We wanted to get that tradition back on deck and to overcome the abuses that had been occurring.

The experiment was put in place for one week. Of course, that is not really long enough for it to be properly evaluated. The purpose of this motion is to allow a longer period, that is, three weeks in all. I think in the meantime the matter should perhaps go to the Procedure Committee and other such bodies for consideration also. But three weeks should be a period in which the Senate can make a proper appreciation of the effects of this reform.

Mr Deputy President, I thought I would give you a couple of examples of the public's reaction to this. The reaction from the public has been incredibly supportive. They are sick and tired of the abuse of Question Time, the abuse of the processes of this place and the abuse of Parliament itself. I will read just two letters to you. The first one was from the ACT, from a woman who said to me:

SPEECH.PARA: I regularly watch the televising of Question Time and listen to the Parliament on radio. It was refreshing to be able to watch and listen to the Senate Question Time this week and find that questions were not only being answered succinctly but that a reasonable number of questions were also being asked. Question Time is at last being used correctly. Congratulations to those who thought of and instigated the new time requirements. I sincerely hope that it will continue to be kept in force and become mandatory for the House of Representatives also.

TALK.START.PARA: —Signed `Mrs Hill'.

—No, my wife does not live in the ACT. This one is from South Australia. I would table the letters, but I suspect the writers might get a call from some of your people. The letter from South Australia says:

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to thank you for replying to my letter and also the information on the Fightback package which I am passing on to friends—
I am pleased to hear that—

but my main reason for writing is to congratulate you on your stand in the Senate at Question Time yesterday. It has brought some sanity into Question Time, which has become abuse time. I notice quite a few glum faces on the Government benches, also the Speaker—
I think that is the President—
who is responsible for what has been going on. Thank you for bringing a little credibility back to the governing of this country.
We will do our best to try to stop this lot from abusing Question Time and they can cooperate by keeping this reform in place for another two weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that the two letters be incorporated in Hansard.

—I will give the same courtesy to the Leader of the Government as he gave to me on a recent occasion when he read from private correspondence. He showed me the private correspondence. I will do that in this instance and show it to him.
—It is nice to know that the Liberals have at least one member in the ACT and one in South Australia who can write such nice letters.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—How many do you have in Victoria?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for that interruption. We, in fact, scored very well in the Victorian election on the weekend in the four seats in which we stood. I would like to put it on the record that the vote augurs extremely well for the coming Federal election. I invite the Opposition to actually have a look at those figures.

PARA.TAB: Turning to the substantive motion which is before us, we support in principle this idea of time limitation; we believe that it worked very well during the trial week. However, we did notice that there was one occasion on which Opposition senators were incapable of asking questions within one minute; we wonder whether they also need to be somewhat restricted.

Noting that several Government Ministers who represent Ministers in the other House simply took questions on notice—despite the fact that they had been given some prior warning of those questions—we seek to amend the motion so that it would provide four minutes for answering the question in the first instance and two minutes for answering a supplementary question. In doing so, I invite those Ministers who represent Ministers in the other place to take questions seriously, because there is little point in asking a question if we do not get an answer to those questions, and that is exactly what happened during the last week of sitting.

In light of the experience of that week, we would like to modify this process for a further fortnight. We believe we will get more information from a modified proposal and, given that change, there is a good chance that Government Ministers will indeed answer all the questions which are asked of them; that will lead to an improvement in Question Time, as outlined in the letters which Senator Hill read out. We certainly want question time and answer time very substantially improved. I move:
Paragraph (a), omit "2 minutes", substitute "4 minutes".

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We had some debate about this matter during the last sitting week so I will not repeat all the arguments for and against the substance of this proposal. There is much heat and not much light being shed in the debate. There were great fulminations by Senator Hill this afternoon; I am delighted he has found two people who want to write to him favourably. I hope that makes him feel much better, but it really does not add anything to the sum of human knowledge.

PARA.TAB: I do not think that, in the long term, this mechanism we are putting in place is going to be a lasting reform that will survive. Nevertheless, we on this side of the House can do fairly rudimentary arithmetic and work out that more than half the Senate is going to vote for some sort of limit. Therefore, in that light, we will be supporting the amendment moved by the Democrats for time limits of four minutes and two minutes.

The issue of answering questions in a representative capacity is not a problem which I personally confront. I have not had a chance to consult with any of my colleagues about this matter because it has only just been raised, but I will discuss it with them before Question Time tomorrow. It is a matter which they may wish to act upon from tomorrow onwards if they so choose. I simply indicate, for the purpose of rounding the debate and shortening subsequent contributions, that when we have finished dealing with this motion, I will seek leave to move a motion relating to the debate on answers given to questions without notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess my profound disappointment at the way in which the Democrats have approached this issue. One would have thought that their track record would suggest that they were particularly interested in getting as many answers as possible, in particular, answers of substance. Not one thing has been said to demonstrate that the two-week exercise that we had during the last sitting was in any way defective other than in respect of a matter which the Democrats raised, that is, a clear breach of the undertakings given by Ministers. They are well paid to answer questions not only directly but also in a representative capacity. They chose not to do that, in a childish tit for tat response, and I thought the Democrats could have recognised that.

PARA.TAB: But in every other respect what we achieved in that last fortnight was a dramatic reduction in the sort of nonsense that people go on with, such as filibustering or simply not answering the question, or `doing a Button', which involves stuttering and stammering and looking around for an interjection which one can then hang a 10-minute answer on. I would have thought, therefore, that what the Democrats ought to have done is to have given that experiment a fair chance, and indeed it has worked to about 90 per cent of expectations. There is only that one area where there has been a lack of bona fides on the part of those opposite and where I would have thought, with a little bit more flushing out, they could have been forced to accept responsibility for answering questions for which they do not have direct responsibility.

Yet the Democrats have now reduced significantly the number of questions that will be answered in this chamber. Once again they have given those opposite the opportunity to go on with all the nonsense. There is nothing to suggest that two minutes is in any way inadequate to give an answer to a question. As the Democrats know, one can take as long as one wants; and if one gets a supplementary, one can do so twice. In every respect that procedure was capable of being made to work perfectly. Yet the Democrats, without giving us any warning—which I think is an indication of how serious they are about the whole exercise—have now provided a forum for the Government to fall back into the bad old ways. The Democrats ought to accept responsibility for that. Clearly, those on the Government benches will grab that opportunity with both hands because it gives them every chance to reduce the number of questions. The Democrats are responsible for that and I hope they will wear it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the remarks of my colleagues Senator Hill and Senator Alston. It is interesting to note from the statistics going back to 1970 that in this chamber apparently every other government but the Hawke-Keating Government could average some 28 to 30

SPEECH.PARA: questions a day. That works out in the hour to an average length of answer of under two minutes. Ministers in this Government apparently cannot reach the standards of all previous governments on which we have been able to compile statistics.

PARA.TAB: The motion that was moved in the last sitting week was an attempt to try to get the Government back to a reasonable standard of behaviour in relation to Question Time and to provide more questions and more time for those questions to be answered. The Australian Democrats today, in widening the ambit and length of time for answers, not only have taken us back to the position in which we were before this motion was moved but have created a climate for Question Time which is now worse.

The community as a whole—and we have seen it in the debate in the other place—is demanding higher standards from the Parliament, and in particular in relation to Question Time. The Democrat response to this today has been to undermine the most significant reform of Question Times which has been put in place in the past decade or so. I seek leave, Mr Deputy President, to incorporate in Hansard a table which shows the numbers of questions answered and the number of supplementary questions raised and answered during the time the current experiment was in place.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: [TABLE OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGES 1124-5]

TALK.START.PARA: —This table outlines the vital statistics on which we need to conduct this debate. These figures show that, during the period of time in which these new rules were in place, some 28 to 34 questions were asked and answered in Question Time compared to some 20 questions asked and answered under the old rules and procedures in the last year.

PARA.TAB: In my view, it is no wonder that Senator Hill received these letters. This was a major reform. It was a major improvement to Question Time and because—as Senator Alston said—a number of Ministers spat the dummy and said they would not answer their questions the Australian Democrats have totally buckled. They have undermined the most important reform to improve Question Time. Whatever private assurances, winks or nods that the Democrats have received from Government Ministers about them agreeing to this reform, they will find that in a fairly short period of time Question Time in this chamber will not only revert to the bad old days but will get worse.

As we have all noticed, we are now heading towards an election and this Government will use—as undoubtedly it is entitled and as we are entitled—every possible vehicle to get its views across. By allowing a Minister four minutes to answer a question—on average, four minutes to answer a question is a far longer time than all Ministers in previous governments took to answer questions—the rules will have been loosened to such an extent that Question Time will go back to the bad old days.

I put it to you, Mr Deputy President, that this is a disgraceful amendment which has been signalled by Senator Coulter and the Australian Democrats. I only hope his colleagues have more regard for the rights of this chamber and the rights of senators and will not support him in this. We have often heard from the Australian Democrats that they are of an independent mind and do not vote the party way. Senator Sowada, Senator Kernot and Senator Bourne will all now be tested as to whether they are prepared to undermine Question Time and follow their leader, Senator Coulter. This is a disgraceful proposal which has been raised by Senator Coulter. Question Time will revert to the bad old days, and I strongly oppose the amendment moved by Senator Coulter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot refrain from requesting Opposition senators to extend the same courtesy they have demanded of Government Ministers—that is, that they not use the opportunity for debate in such a way that they abuse the privilege by petty and irrelevant point scoring. I support the substantive motion on the grounds that the community deserves far better performances than it has yet received from some questioners as well as from some of those answering. The way in which this motion has been introduced is a particular example of this.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. What we are now seeing is clearly part of an orchestrated campaign—reading a question. It is meant to be a question without notice and it clearly is not. I therefore invite you, Mr Deputy President, to direct the honourable senator that this is not a question without notice but a prepared text presumably prepared by others and, therefore, does not fall within the Standing Orders.
—I do believe that Senator Chamarette is referring to notes.

—I am referring to the motion under debate and, if Opposition senators would care to listen, they might actually hear that I am in agreement with what they are suggesting. Recently, in a mock parliament held by high school students in this place, I heard a disappointing and sad imitation of the manners they have come to expect of Federal parliamentarians. In relation to the substantive motion, I support—
—You had written out your little speech before you had even heard the argument.

—I was busy writing my notes as I listened to the stimulating debate which was going on in this place. It gave me plenty of opportunity to prepare my thoughts. I am merely referring to them to try to be succinct, as I wish the Opposition would be. To conclude my remarks, I support the Opposition's motion regarding the two-minute time limit on the grounds that a cogent answer can be made in two minutes and a four-minute time period will only allow twelve questions—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Chamarette has the floor.

—Thank you for the illustration of the point I am trying to make. Allowing points of order and a lengthy time, such as four minutes, may actually extend a temptation to honourable senators which the spirit of the motion, which I support, will not allow—that is, a time restriction of two minutes. I support the motion.

—It is unfortunate that clear self-interest appears to have become the ultimate motive for the Australian Democrats in this debate. It is evident from the figures Senator Kemp has tabled that the Australian Democrats were getting two questions per day under the old arrangement and are getting two questions per day under the arrangement we intend to proceed with. The figures showed that in fact Government senators and Opposition senators had benefited from the opportunity to ask many more questions under the temporary arrangements which we hope to continue. In other words, the Australian Democrats' interest in this procedure bears no relationship to the benefit to the Parliament, but it does to their own self-interest exclusively.

PARA.TAB: Because they have not received extra questions they see no merit in maintaining this increased volume of questions. The scheme they are proposing could limit Question Time to a total of eight questions of which the Opposition would get four; that is, eight primary questions and eight supplementary questions. This is worse than the situation that existed before we introduced this system. We—

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixteen.

—Exactly, 16—eight major questions and eight supplementaries. That is exactly the number that was asked on 10 September. That was the situation we sought to remedy. It is remarkable that after we changed the system 34 questions were asked on 14 September and 34 questions were asked on 15 September. Then the Government got its act together and started to run phoney supplementaries and so on and we ended up with 28 questions being asked. But at least 28 questions were asked in the last two days of this system. Under the proposal the Democrats are putting up, the number of questions asked in Question Time could be cut to eight major questions and eight supplementaries. This is just ludicrous. I do not know whether the Democrats have recognised the consequences of what they are doing. Maybe they have.
—They have done a deal.

—As my Leader interjects, no doubt there is a deal. Let us recognise this: when only 16 questions and supplementaries were asked on 10 September, the crisis day that brought forward this change, the Democrats had two questions. In other words, they have not directly benefited.

PARA.TAB: On the contrary, they may feel they have been perhaps put down a little because the amount of time taken by Government Ministers to respond to Democrat questions has fallen from 2.33 minutes per question to 1.27 minutes per question. Perhaps the Democrats are concerned that they are not being taken seriously enough by the Government. I have always thought Government Ministers were taking them far too seriously. If we in this chamber would recognise more the benefits to the Parliament of this change rather than focus on the very narrow, selfish, self-interest of the Australian Democrats, this chamber would proceed far more satisfactorily. I urge those members of the Australian Democrats who do have some concern for this place to vote in support of Senator Hill's motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to speak for the five minutes I am allotted; I simply want to make a number of comments. Some time ago, I think about seven years ago, former Senator Reg Withers said that the period of time in the day we call `Questions Without Notice' should be referred to as `Questions Without Answers'. From the time former Senator Withers first said that up until the last couple of weeks, the Government has taken that to an absolute art form. The Government used the time to avoid giving a proper answer to a simple question and to either advertise their own policies, which they could do in a ministerial statement, or simply try to do a bucket job on the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: In the last fortnight we saw a change for the better. Ministers had to answer questions in an articulate fashion within two minutes and could have another two minutes to answer supplementary questions if their first answers were not adequate. Ministers with any real capacity, which divides some of those opposite anyway, and a reasonable ego can easily give an articulate answer in two minutes. Those two requirements—having a reasonable capacity and a limited ego—cut out a significant portion of those on the other side. Nonetheless, it is the case that someone with a decent capacity and a limit on his or her ego can answer articulately within the two-minute time frame.

My third point is this: questions without notice are not for the benefit of the Government; they are for the benefit of those who want to question the Executive. Questions without notice are not for the benefit of Ministers to give answers. The whole purpose of Question Time is for us, the Australian Democrats and others on this side who might like to ask questions to ask them and get answers; it is not to suit Ministers—that is, it is for the benefit of the asker and not the answerer.

I put it to the Democrats that it is not a question of whether a Minister wants four minutes to answer a question; it is a question of whether the person asking the question is happy with the answer that he or she gets in a two-minute time frame. If he or she is not happy with the answer given because that person thinks it is inadequate in some way, he or she can ask a supplementary question. Therefore, the Minister will have another two minutes to answer. That is how we should be looking at it.

If we are unhappy with the answers, we will ask supplementary questions—not give Ministers four minutes to begin with. If we give Ministers four minutes to begin with, we will have more of Senator Evans giving himself a buzz by practising his word skills and reminding himself how clever he is, Senator Cook yet again bumbling the reading of his briefs—he has displayed a manifest incapacity to answer questions without them—and Senator Collins displaying yet again his total incapacity to answer a question in two minutes because he misses out on the bad job that a four-minute answer would provide him with.

For those reasons, we should stick with the two-minute time frame. In that way, we can ascertain who has any real capacity to answer a question articulately. We should leave it to the person asking the question to decide whether he or she wants more information or to ask a supplementary question, which will give more time to Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could we just for a moment be a bit practical and even a little fair and reasonable? From my experience of the last sitting week, it is my view that two minutes is unfortunately too short for people to give answers. In the last sitting week when genuine questions of substance were asked—and I mean genuine questions of substance, which were often by the Australian Democrats—Ministers were genuinely unable to complete their answers within two minutes. Therefore, what did we see? We saw the novelty of all these artificial supplementary questions from the Labor Party.
—No, they weren't.
—Senator Sherry's was a particularly good example. I would rather us revert to having real supplementary questions.

PARA.TAB: While talking of time taken up in Question Time, let us not forget the spurious points of order that are raised by the Opposition, 98 per cent of which are not upheld. Four minutes will eliminate artificial supplementaries and give the Minister a reasonable time to answer. Four minutes is totally reasonable. It is not compulsory; it is an option. I remind members of the Opposition that this motion is for a two-week trial. We are quite obviously evolving into some other form. In two weeks we can evaluate the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disappointing to hear that the Democrats have succumbed to pressure from the Government. I say that for the very simple reason that this proposed amendment will leave us in a worse situation than the one we were in prior to the alteration. The fact is that the new sessional order was brought in in a sense of desperation. It set a time limit of two minutes for answers given by the Government. The reason for that is amply displayed by analysis of the statistics. They clearly show that the very lengthy answers which the Government would indulge in were given in answer to dorothy dixers. They lasted for five minutes on average.

PARA.TAB: The introduction of the two-minute answer for a trial period of a week met with good response from the general public. This Question Time is meant to be part of the checks and balances of our system of government. It is meant to be a time when questions are asked of executive government and Ministers are meant to give answers as part of the scrutiny process. They are meant to be accountable for their actions. Too often again and again we saw clear examples of the dorothy dixer being used by a Minister to make a ministerial statement which, quite frankly, ought to be done at a different time in the agenda of the Parliament.

We agreed as a body to use for a period of one week the limitation of two minutes. By extending it to four minutes and two minutes we are reverting to a position which is worse than the situation we were in previously. We will have fewer and fewer questions and return to the abuse of Question Time—time that is used either to abuse the Opposition or to make a ministerial statement.

I said it is disappointing to see that the Democrats have succumbed to pressure from the Government because there is no other rational reason for this amendment to take place. If they are honest in saying that we wanted to have a true trial, we would continue the trial that we put in place for one week for at least a fortnight to allow Ministers to get used to the new system whereby they have to be succinct and pertinent to the question asked. If that were to be the case, at the end of the day after a true trial the Democrats may say, `Let's discuss some slight modification'. But they simply want to go back to the old system—quite frankly, back to the bad old days. If the public is to be considered and properly served, we will reject the amendment of the Democrats and we will simply support, as Senator Chamarette has done, the substantive motion moved by Senator Hill.

TALK.START.PARA: —My preference would be for no sessional order to be adopted which would replace the existing Standing Orders, because I have always maintained that the Standing Orders, if observed, would ensure that questions be answered directly—
—They never are.

—It is true that they are not being observed, but what I said last time holds true for this occasion as well. I believe that the onus ought to be on the Government to ensure that Ministers' responses are within the Standing Orders. The onus ought to be on the people who are asking Ministers questions—whether they be members of the Government, Opposition members, Democrats or Independents—to do so within Standing Orders. If all that were done, there would be no need for such a sessional order.

PARA.TAB: Given the fact that we are now presented with two possibilities—the one that was moved by Senator Hill, that is, the two-minute limit for answers, and the amendment moved by Senator Coulter, the four-minute response—I would prefer the two-minute limit. From experience, it seems to me that once members of Parliament are given a time, they tend to talk to that time.
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I can hear around the place a good deal of support for that statement. My concern under those circumstances—as was pointed out previously in the debate—is that the four-minute response would cut down substantially the number of questions that could be asked and could be answered. It would not cut down the number of questions that the Democrats could ask at all. They would have the same number of questions.
—So would you.

—No, I would not. Whether it is a four-minute response or a two-minute response, the Democrats would have the same response. I have not done the figures, but I have done other figures in the past and I would beg to say that my opportunity and the opportunity of Independents would in fact be affected under those circumstances. I stand to be corrected on that but, off the top of my head, I think our opportunities would be more limited under the proposal put forward by the Democrats than that put forward by the Opposition. Not out of self-interest but out of the interests of the people that elected me, I feel under those circumstances that I should vote for the motion of the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the Prime Minister's 11 September statement welcoming President Bush's plan for a network of free trade agreements, in which Mr Keating said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . is a welcome signal that the United States recognises the need to take part in building more liberal trading arrangement in the Pacific area.

PARA.TAB: His—

QUESTION.PARA: proposal to conclude a series of Free Trade Agreements with Pacific countries could provide a stimulus for the trade liberalising process of the APEC community of nations.

I ask the Minister: what occurred to change the Prime Minister's mind in the space of 11 days, in that 11 days later in Japan he labelled President Bush's proposal as manipulative and said it was a product of a lack of American confidence? How does attacking the United States in Japan further Australia's interests? Did the Prime Minister, in his efforts to ingratiate himself to the Japanese, take into account the damage he was doing to the Australian-US relationship—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time has expired for the question.

—It is not a matter of the Prime Minister changing his mind or changing his statement of policy in any way. It is simply a matter of clearly articulating Australia's priorities. Australia's priorities are, clearly, firstly, to achieve global trade liberalisation; secondly, to advance the cause of regional trade liberalisation in a manner not inconsistent with global liberalisation; and a long way down the list of the hierarchy of preferences for us is the pursuit of subregional or bilateral free trade arrangements.

PARA.TAB: We acknowledge that, in principle, such arrangements can constitute building blocs towards the establishment of those larger free trade areas or principles. But in practice there is a very real difficulty about making that assumption, particularly with bilateral arrangements in which the United States is a partner.

As this matter was given closer attention and, in particular, in the light of the extraordinarily embarrassing embrace that was directed towards the United States by the Leader of the Opposition in complete indifference to Australia's larger trade policy interests in the Asian region, and in particular with our northern neighbours, it became apparent that there really did need to be stated more firmly Australia's reservations about the down side risks of focusing too much attention on bilateral arrangements.

Those risks, so far as Australia is concerned, can very simply be stated. In the first place, it is very difficult for us to be able to contemplate a bilateral trade arrangement with the United States in which the benefits to us would manifestly outweigh the costs. Secondly, any such arrangement, if multiplied between us and a number of other so-called spokes, with the United States as its hub, would be very likely to create not an ease in the trading environment but, in the first instance at least, a greater degree of difficulty in the trade patterns as between the United States partners.

In the third place, we would argue, and have argued very articulately through the Prime Minister, that to place the emphasis on a pattern of individual relationships like this with the United States rather than on the larger regional and global strategy is really to miss the basic point and to miss the real interests of the Australian economy and Australian exporters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister's answer could have been the answer of Mr Keating back in Australia before he went to Japan but it was not. Mr Keating said that the move by President Bush was a welcome signal. My question was: why did he go to Japan to attack the United States? Why did he change his mind? When will this Prime Minister, Mr Keating, learn that it is possible to build new relationships without destroying old ones?

—The statement by President Bush was a welcomed statement in an in-principle commitment to the principle of free trade and the achievement of free trade in the Pacific arena. That is the particular aspect of that statement on which the Prime Minister chose to concentrate in his initial statement.

PARA.TAB: In subsequent statements he has made it clear that our preference, as I have just said, is overwhelmingly for regional or larger global based arrangements rather than bilateral ones. That is the context in which we have constantly been articulating Australian policy the whole time that this has been in issue.

It is not a matter of doing anything to attack the United States. This has not been anything in the nature of an attack upon the United States. It has just been a clear-cut and articulate expression of the reality that we are in a $5 billion annual trading deficit with the United States and a $6 billion annual trading surplus with Japan.

In that kind of environment, in particular, one where 60 per cent of our exports go to Asia and only less than 10 per cent go to the United States—just over 11 per cent to the NAFTA countries as a whole—it is manifestly in Australia's interests to be focusing to our north, not yearning after the environment of yesteryear so far as economic issues are concerned, which is the position of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Transport and Communications advise the Senate when the new Australian Broadcasting Authority commences operation? Why is the Government replacing the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal with the new Authority? What impact are the new arrangements likely to have on the broadcasting industry and, more importantly, the Australian consumer?

—I am pleased to advise the Senate that the new Broadcasting Authority opened its doors for business this morning. I was fortunate enough to be able to be present at that occasion and launched its new logo. The opening of business for the new Authority and the new Broadcasting Act, which took effect yesterday, mark the commencement of a new broadcasting regime in this country. The new regime is the result of an enormous amount of work to bring the 50-year-old Broadcasting Act of 1942 up to date and to provide us with a legislative framework which will take us into the next century. Given the dramatic changes that the new Broadcasting Services Act brings with it, the Government decided that the establishment of a new authority to administer the new regime was the appropriate way to go.

PARA.TAB: The Broadcasting Services Act gives effect to the Government's 1987 election commitment, reiterated in 1990, to establish an appropriate regulatory framework for the broadcasting industry that will serve Australia into the twenty-first century. It is also a further significant milestone in this Government's micro-economic reform agenda, which has already achieved landmark reforms in telecommunications, aviation, the national rail system and the waterfront. The new Act provides a framework for broadcasting regulation which can respond to future technological changes. The charter of the Broadcasting Authority is designed to provide for regulatory responsiveness to accommodate this change and, in doing so, to minimise regulatory intervention.

The new regime is clearly essential to enable the broadcasting industry to respond to the complexities of the modern marketplace and the opportunities created by an ever changing technological landscape. The Australian telecommunications manufacturing sector will also be a winner in a far more dynamic broadcasting environment. Finally, Australian consumers will be the big winners because they will have greater access to a far more diverse range of services.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the comments of his Victorian colleague and former Premier, Mrs Kirner, on the ABC's Four Corners program last night, when she said:

QUESTION.PARA: I firmly believe that [the Prime Minister] will have to shift on his tariff policy before his election.
It would have been nice had he shifted it before my election.

I ask: now that the Federal Labor Party has got its wish and the grossly incompetent Victorian Labor Government has been summarily sacked by the electorate, will the Keating Government accept Mrs Kirner's advice and shift its tariff policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a pretty tortuous sort of question. We have had the benefit of advice from all sorts of people about our tariff policy and we have announced it over a long period. It has been done largely on the basis of Industry Commission reports. It is consistent with this Government's views. We will no doubt get further advice from various people, but the policy has been announced. We will make assessments of any good advice we get and act on it if necessary.
—You are being wobbly.

—I know that the honourable senator is very worried about that issue. His Leader has been out making statements to various people in the motor vehicle industry about this matter and suggesting all sorts of things, which the honourable senator is quite upset about. The main advice we got from Mrs Kirner was at the time there was a move on to produce a pause in the textiles, clothing and footwear tariff reductions. We rejected that advice then. That was advice which we rejected in somewhat difficult circumstances for the Victorian Government. We are not likely to change our view, I am sorry.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I wonder whether the Minister could have another go at it and try to give the Senate an unequivocal answer as to whether the Government will or will not shift its tariff policy. In the light of the answer he has already given, I also ask whether Mr Keating and Bob Hogg, to coin a recent phrase, have taken a big loss—a big L-O-S-S.

—The last part of the question is not a supplementary question. As far as the first part of the question is concerned, if Senator Short did not understand my answer, let me say it simply again. We have announced our tariff policies over the years. We have always received advice from all sorts of industries and people about those tariff policies. We listen to that advice, as distinct from the Opposition. We have not accepted it; we have never accepted it. We make up our own minds about these issues. This Government has a sophisticated tariff policy, which is more than can be said for the lot opposite.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition's tariff policy and its industry policies generally are worked out on the basis of some economic model here in Canberra or somewhere else. Those things work in theory. We are concerned about what works in practice. I again make the point that we listen to the views of industry, but we have made up our own minds, on the basis of an assessment of all sorts of views which we receive, about what the tariff policy would be. It is in place. It will not change.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to remarks made by the Opposition's industrial relations spokesperson, Mr John Howard, on last night's ABC news where he said that `within twelve months you'll have an enormously beneficial industrial relations revolution throughout Australia'. Can the Minister advise whether the Government will adopt the Opposition's big bang approach to industrial relations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

A quiet revolution has been going on for some time in Australian industrial relations. That quiet revolution will continue—

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This question was simply a question asked by the Government of the Minister so that he could comment gratuitously on Opposition policy. PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—The two people who watch this program when it is repeated on television will be sorely disappointed by the performance of the Opposition here today. The question reads: can the Minister advise whether the Government will adopt the Opposition's big bang approach to industrial relations?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I refer you to a ruling made by President Sibraa on 19 February 1987, in which he noted a similarity to a point of order which I raised before, where he said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I will allow it on the basis that the Minister answers only that part of the question that dealt with her portfolio and the Government's policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is in order. I call Senator Cook.

—I note the concerted efforts of the Opposition to gag me in talking about industrial relations. Obviously, Opposition senators regard that as their weak spot and therefore want the good news about the continuing quiet revolution in Australian industrial relations not to get out. It is true that for some time now there has been a quiet revolution in changing Australian workplaces. It has gone on without dispute. We are enjoying a record level of industrial peace in this country. It has not gone on with any need for a big bang. Continuing benefit has been coming through the system. We are making those changes in a managed way and the important thing is that those changes are working.

PARA.TAB: When Mr Howard said what he did last night, he may have been trying to draw some succour from the election result on the weekend. The coalition campaigned strongly on industrial relations in the Queensland election and was comprehensively defeated there. Therefore, he cannot gain any national succour from that result.

In the case of Victoria, governments do claim when they come to office that they have mandates for a whole range of things. But the important facts about Victoria are that the Liberals announced industrial relations policies on 23 April, 29 June, 23 and 26 August and last week, and on all occasions they made more vague the terms of what it was that they were proposing—but they announced on Monday that they had a Bill ready to introduce. It would have been very useful if the Bill that they had ready on Monday had been made available last week so that the electorate could scrutinise the actual contents of the legislation. They did not make it available, and I think that speaks for itself. But, most importantly about the weekend, the exit polls show that people voted on financial management of the Government and that the gap between the parties was closed because of the industrial relations policy of the Opposition.

As I have said, we have been enjoying a record level of industrial peace. I do not think it can be said that there is a clear mandate cast in concrete for industrial relations reform in Victoria based on the election outcome in that State. We have been enjoying record industrial peace in this country, and I will continue to work, as I have been, with State Ministers of all political persuasions to ensure that that record remains intact. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. What funding has the Government agreed to provide for the ABC's international television service into Asia, both on a start-up basis and on an ongoing basis? Is part of this agreement with the ABC that it will seek funding from sponsorship for the service and, if so, for how much? Is it possible to find this funding from any other source? Finally, will the Minister undertake that sponsorship on the ABC would be absolutely restricted to overseas television and that any legislative changes would reflect that?
—The answer to the last part of Senator Bourne's question is a categorical yes.
—Until you change your mind again.

—There will be no extension of that sponsorship into Australia. In response to the interjection, I noted that the Opposition's shadow Minister for communications, Warwick Smith, publicly stated that that would also be the Opposition's position, I am pleased to say.

PARA.TAB: I think this is probably one of the better value for money exercises in terms of advancing Australia's presence in this region that I have seen for some time. I think that Senator Evans, who was the co-sponsor of this in Cabinet, would agree with that assessment. The actual amount of money which the Government will contribute to this exercise is $5.4m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce confirm the major new investment in Australia by the international pharmaceutical company Glaxo; and can he tell the Senate what role the Government has played in the recent development of that industry and the Glaxo development in particular?

—All commentators now seem to characterise the pharmaceutical industry as a high growth industry in Australia—and it is because it is a very high value-added industry. It is true that Glaxo opened a new $10m product development centre, which is really a laboratory, at its headquarters in Melbourne on Monday morning of this week; I was there.

PARA.TAB: It is a product development centre, not a manufacturing centre as such. As a product development centre, it uses the highly developed research, medical and scientific base which we have in Australia and uses a lot of skills which have been developed in this country. The pharmaceutical industry development program, which the Government has sponsored, has been very important in changing Australia's reputation as a place to invest for this important industry.

For many years Australia had an impressive research base but very little investment in the pharmaceutical industry. Investment was scared off by two things: firstly, the way the governments of the day kept prices for drugs down well below world average prices and, secondly, a very complex drug approval system.

The Government's pharmaceutical industry development program addresses the first issue of price relating to companies that are developing pharmaceutical products in Australia and exporting from Australia. The estimate of the companies and the Government is that those exports will reach in excess of $2 billion by the end of this decade from this industry.

In so far as the regulatory environment for the pharmaceutical industry was concerned, the Government called on the services of ex-Senator Peter Baume, in his capacity as a professor of community medicine, to review the regulatory environment and his report was immensely helpful in getting the changes which have been made to the regulatory environment. That is not to say that the environment for pharmaceutical companies is perfect, but there is a better balance between the Government's objectives in controlling health costs and industry development.

The Opposition rejects the notion that there is a role for government in fostering growth in particular industries and growth in exports, but many of the top exporting companies are supported by the pragmatic, innovative industry programs of this Government. I am not just talking about pharmaceuticals. I am talking about steel, shipbuilding, motor vehicles, software and telecommunication equipment which are examples of that and which are largely all at the high value-added end of industry development in this country.

I appreciate Senator Zakharov's interest in this matter. I know that the Glaxo announcement on Monday was part of an ongoing program of investment by that company. Other major world pharmaceutical companies are investing in Australia, and we very much welcome that. It is very important for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to his recent notorious assertion to the Manufacturing Outlook Conference that the Government has undertaken a good deal of micro-economic reform and, in the Government's opinion, `about as much micro-economic reform as the community can digest in such a short time'. Why has the Government thrown in the towel on micro-economic reform in Australia when the cream of the Australian business community has made it abundantly clear that they want the process accelerated?

—If Senator Alston is going to ask questions like this, he should understand some of the issues involved. The first point I ought to make about that is that this was a manufacturing outlook seminar in which the question of industry policy was the subject of discussion.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston may not know this, but tariff reform—something the Opposition never did when it was in government—is a key element of micro-economic reform. I make no apologies for the fact that on tariff reform, which is a crucial aspect of micro-economic reform, this Government has changed the whole ball game in this country in terms of general tariffs and tariffs for the two planned industries of textiles, clothing and footwear and the automotive industry.

I said at the time that the speed limit in relation to tariff reform is as announced by the Government. There is no question of throwing in the towel on that. The question of tariff reform is very important, and that is a key micro-economic reform. If Senator Alston would like to consult my speech, he will see a number of statements relating to other types of micro-economic reforms which follow tariff reform. I did not suggest for a moment we were stalling the process. I said that the next few years will see even more competition and pressures for change and not only in the traded goods and services sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister seriously suggesting that micro-economic reform is really the same as tariff reform and can therefore be equated? What does he make of the Business Council's recent submission that `keeping the economy open by reducing protection and accelerating the pace of micro-economic reforms and labour market reforms will be the key to achieving international competitiveness'? What does he make of John Gough saying that the tariff question is not going to be the critical one but that it is going to be micro-economic reform? John Gough knows the difference. Is Senator Button pretending there is no difference?

—If Senator Alston wants to wallow in his ignorance on these issues, I ask him to ask another supplementary. I did not say that tariff reform was the same thing as micro-economic reform. I said it was a key aspect of micro-economic reform, and it is.
—What have you given up on?

—Let me answer the question for once. Every question is approached with an open mouth by Senator Alston. In my earlier answer I said that this Government has made its position on tariff reform quite clear. It is on the agenda. General tariffs to be phased to 1996, automotive phased over a certain period, and TCF phased over a certain period. I said that we believe that in terms of tariff adjustment that is what the community absorbs.
—Why did you use the term `micro-economic' instead of just talking about tariffs?

—If Senator Alston does not want to hear the answer he should keep shouting and yelling his silly head off, but I am giving him the answer. I have no difficulty with what the Business Council said. I have to tell Senator Alston that this Government invented tariff reform. The Business Council did not know about it when this Government started on its program of tariff reform. The Business Council did not have any view about it at that time.

PARA.TAB: It is all very well to quote from what Mr Gough said last week in the particular context of one industry. The fact of the matter is that I have no difficulty with what the Business Council says about that at all. What I do have difficulty with is some industrialists who have never operated in the traded goods sector of the Australian economy and some industrialists who have had their hand out year after year for various benefits which have accrued to their industry—gold tax, for example—suddenly saying that they believe these things are wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services seen the report in today's Australian Financial Review of proposals by State Liberal health Ministers to meet to oppose the Medicare hospital arrangements? Does this put at risk the prospect for Medicare arrangements with the States?

—I have not seen the report in the Financial Review that Senator Crowley refers to, but I did see on television last night the State Minister for Health in New South Wales encouraging his Victorian colleague to try to sabotage the arrangements that are being foreshadowed as the subject of discussion with the Federal Minister for Health in a few weeks' time. Of course, that would be disastrous for the health of Australians. What is at stake is a revamping of Medicare so that there is a proper dealing with the insurance aspects of health care for all Australians. Also at stake is the whole question of comprehensive health care for Australians. I know that in my home State of Tasmania the rural health program will be a very important part of that particular overall health approach.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the Federal Government has said that $1.6 billion will be available for the State public hospital systems over the next five years under these Medicare arrangements. That is a considerable increase in funding to those institutions where Australians will want to seek care and hospital treatment rather than be dependent on the private hospital system, which is the idol of the Opposition parties.

The Opposition will take $1.3 billion away from the public hospitals system and use it to subsidise private health insurance premiums. It will force people to take out private health insurance premiums in addition to the levy and their normal taxation payments in order to make some sort of health system available to Australians. That is quite incredible. In fact, we believe we are on the right track in saying that more money ought to be provided for the public hospitals system, which is greatly appreciated by most Australians seeking hospital care.

I believe that the health Ministers in New South Wales and Victoria would be well advised to take advantage of the discussions concerning the revamped Medicare agreement that are to be initiated over the next few weeks. Should misfortune strike and the Opposition ever come into government, under its policies, 5 per cent will be slashed from the funds made available to the States, which means that less money will be available from the State treasuries to fund their public hospitals. There will be a deterioration in the public hospitals and less access to public hospital beds by ordinary Australians. Fear will drive those Australians to take out private health insurance. The Opposition's objective is that people fund the health care system through their contributions to the private health insurance premium system, or else the Opposition will subsidise it by taking money away from public hospitals.

I believe it is extremely important that we remove people's fear that they will not have sufficient access to public hospitals. We will ensure that the public hospital system throughout Australia operates well, efficiently and in a way which satisfies the real clinical needs of Australians. That will be done under the new Medicare arrangements that are foreshadowed.

I bet that the Liberal Ministers from around Australia will take advantage of that offer rather than leave themselves in the position where they might lose that 5 per cent funding to the States and therefore find themselves confronted with a real reduction in funding for public hospitals. That is something they will not want to face. I am quite sure that they will take up this offer and that the political posturing will soon come to an end.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to comments made last week by six of Australia's most prominent senior executives, who are all members of the Business Council of Australia, which opposed the pro-tariffs campaign that is being run by the multinational car industry—an industry in which the Government is showing itself to be a soft target for car lobbyists. I particularly refer to Woodside Petroleum's managing director, Mr Charles Allen, who said that there was not much sympathy for the car industry in senior business circles. He said:

Does the Minister agree with Mr Allen's comments and those of other members of the BCA?

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition senators should get their heads clear about some of these things. It is all very well for somebody like Charles Allen to makes these comments. Look at the tax treatment which the North West Shelf project got from governments in this country in order to get it off the ground. Those opposite talk about other industries, but members of the car industry do not go around saying, `Look at the assistance which the goldminers got from the tax exemption. Look at the assistance which North West Shelf got'. It could do that if it wanted to. I would not get excited about this.

PARA.TAB: There have been all these accusations about listening to the car industry lobby. Senator Campbell should listen and try to understand what we did, if he can get it into his head. In 1991, we adopted an Industry Commission report which made recommendations about the future of the car industry in the face of opposition from the car industry, which wanted a higher in-point tariff. The Opposition then comes in here and asks me questions about yielding to the car industry lobby.

The Industry Commission report that was adopted by this Government set down a program of reform in tariffs for the car industry to the year 2000. If those opposite do not like it, they should get the report out and, for the first time in their lives, tell us in their newly born view where the Industry Commission is wrong about this issue. If Senator Campbell wants to get an understanding of that he should look at the speech made by Hugh Morgan in his city of Perth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Senator Button has referred to mining leaders as liars. I wonder whether that is a parliamentary comment and, if not, would you ask him to withdraw it?
—Senator Button did not do that.
—That is a grubby little point. I said that the statements made by mining industry leaders are based on lies which they have been given.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: that is precisely what I said. Senator Button said it is based on lies and he is calling mining industry leaders liars.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I do not wish to respond to this amateur Goebbels from Victoria on these sorts of issues, but I am quite clear about what I said and the Hansard will show what I said. I make it quite clear that in respect of this issue the views of various business leaders are of course of interest, but that is not the question. Every industry has its own particular interest to look after and so on.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the attitude of the Australian Government to the human rights situation which confronts the tribal people in the Chittagong Hill Tracts area of Bangladesh? Does the Government view this issue with concern? Has the Australian Government expressed such concern to the Government of Bangladesh, or does it propose to do so?

—I thank Senator Loosley for bringing this matter to public attention because it has received less attention internationally than it deserves. The Australian Government has certainly been deeply concerned about the situation in the Chittagong Hill Tracts and distressed at recent clashes between tribal and non-tribal communities. We view with concern reports that Bangladesh security forces have been less than diligent in keeping the peace in the CHT or partial in their approach to the conflict. It is essential that the rights of all citizens of Bangladesh be protected equally without fear or favour.

PARA.TAB: We do welcome indications that both parties are willing to negotiate. The Shanti Bahini—tribal insurgents—have declared a three-month truce from 10 August to 10 November. I take this opportunity to urge the Government of Bangladesh to seize every opportunity to engage in a constructive dialogue with all concerned parties.

We have expressed our concern to the Government of Bangladesh on a number of occasions following a clash between tribal and non-tribal communities on 10 April this year. The High Commission in Dhaka conveyed our concern to relevant authorities and urged that a comprehensive inquiry be conducted, with those found responsible being brought to justice. An official from the High Commission subsequently visited the area and spoke with individuals from all interested parties based on that visit and other information.

Our High Commissioner made further representations to the Government on 16 August and encouraged it again to reach a negotiated settlement. Our High Commissioner also expressed the Government's concern that Bangladesh security forces did not seem to be protecting adequately the tribal people or preserving peace in the Hill Tracts. We have tasked our High Commissioner to follow and report on the progress of an inquiry committee which has been established by the Government to investigate possibilities for a peaceful solution.

Finally, I am concerned that, following the gazettal in May this year of approximately 150,000 acres of land in the Chittagong Hill Tracts as reserved forest, the Government of Bangladesh may now seek to remove some 20,000 tribal families from this area. Admittedly, this is not a straightforward or simple issue but relocating these people at this time would clearly only exacerbate what is already a volatile situation. We will continue to monitor closely developments in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to the High Court decision to throw out the Government's anti-democratic ban on political advertising, described in the Weekend Australian as one of the `most embarrassing policy debacles in almost 10 years of Labor government'. Is it true that over $1m was spent on the Minister's futile attempt to curtail freedom of speech? Will he now provide the Senate with a detailed breakdown of the costs involved in the flawed exercise, in particular the legal costs associated with the Government's defence in the High Court? Finally, will he release the legal advice supporting the legislation so that everyone can be assured that it was contrary legal advice rather than political expediency and self-interest that was the reason the Government proceeded with the ad ban?

—I thank Senator Parer for his somewhat belated question. I must admit that when the High Court made its decision and announced it some three or four weeks ago I thought I might be getting a few questions then. Obviously, someone has got into Senator Parer over the last few weeks and we have a question this afternoon and a matter of public importance as well.
—They've come out with reasons now.

—I know the High Court has come out with reasons now. They are reasons which not only I find very interesting but also, I am sure, my colleague Senator Evans, who for a long time has been pursuing them; he would have found them even more interesting then than he does now. In respect of the article in the Australian, which I think was written by Peter Wilson—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, if Opposition senators want me to give an answer, I would appreciate not having to put up with this babble on the other side. If those opposite want an answer I will give a straight answer but the injecting and the squabbling on the other side does not really help. Senator Parer quite rightly asked a couple questions. I am about to answer those questions and I will do so very well without the assistance of Senator Campbell, Senator Bishop and the others opposite.

PARA.TAB: In respect of releasing the advice, I made it very clear some time ago that I saw no need to deviate from a long held position in this place that we do not release legal advice. In respect of the decision, let me say one or two things. No-one in the debate over the years on this particular issue would ever have imagined the concept of freedom of political communication being embraced by the High Court in the way that it was. The only person in the High Court who, some five or six years ago, even contemplated such a principle was His Honour Justice Lionel Murphy. He was very much on his own at that particular time. I think it is fair to say that no-one involved in the committee hearings or in debate in this place would have expected the sort of decision—and also the reasoning behind the decision—made by the High Court.

In closing, having seen the ads placed by the Federal Liberal Party over recent weeks, I must say that if we had realised that it would be doing that sort of advertising we probably would not have tried to ban it; we would have made it compulsory.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to Senator Collins as Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport the Environment and Territories. It relates to the Minister's recent decisions concerning Benders Quarry and the protection of Exit Cave in Tasmania. What is the content and timetable of the agreement struck with the Tasmanian Government and Mr Bender, the operator of the quarry? What is the precise rehabilitation work that has been agreed to? What compensation has been promised and to whom? Who will determine the appropriate rehabilitation techniques that are to be used?

—The Minister provided me with the following information which I think will answer all the parts of Senator Bell's question. The agreement between the Commonwealth, Tasmania and Benders Pty Ltd allows for no further blasting at the quarry and all quarrying in the active quarry area to cease by the end of January 1993. It also allows for the preparation of a rehabilitation plan by the Commonwealth, taking into account Australia's obligations under the World Heritage Convention and the Tasmanian Environment Protection Act, having primary regard for the values of the World Heritage area and providing for the safety requirements as set out in the Tasmanian Mines Inspection Act. The Commonwealth will appoint an independent adviser who will work with the on-site supervising agent to oversee implementation of the rehabilitation plan. It is anticipated that rehabilitation work will utilise existing plant and equipment and provide employment to existing quarry workers.

PARA.TAB: Approximately 3,000 tonnes of loose rock will be removed from the benches to meet limestone supply requirements. After the completion of the rehabilitation plan, a further 9,000 tonnes will be extracted by mechanical means, of which approximately 3,000 tonnes will be available for rehabilitation purposes. The form of mechanical treatment of the benches will be determined by the rehabilitation plan. There is in fact some material here which is not relevant to the question. I will just answer the question. The specific rehabilitation work will be determined by the rehabilitation plan.

The answer to the last part of Senator Bell's question is that the rehabilitation consultant will determine the appropriate techniques, drawing upon previous reports on the continuation of quarrying and its effects on the World Heritage values of the Exit Caves system. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask the Minister whether, on their recent visits to Washington, he and Mr Kerin were able to obtain any assurances that the US would not use EEP subsidised wheat to target Australian markets. How do these assurances and past assurances from President Bush square with the latest EEP subsidised sales to India and Pakistan? Could the latest sale to India of one million tonnes be considered as a retaliation for the Prime Minister's verbal assault on US trade policies on his recent visit to Japan?

—It takes a rather perverse cast of mind to regard it as a retaliatory step when one takes into account, quite apart from anything else, the fact that it was on 2 September, well before the Prime Minister's visit to Japan, that the basic EEP allocation of 29 million tonnes of wheat was announced. As part of that, India was specifically designated as a target market, as indeed was Pakistan, with a sum of 1.5 million tonnes of wheat being identified alongside India in that respect. That is something that obviously gave us cause for concern at the time when the sales were merely in prospect. Obviously, we have even more concern now that those sales have been announced. But it cannot be argued to have been something totally unforeseen, unanticipated and unexpected.

PARA.TAB: It does not make it any easier to accommodate, the decision now having been made, first with Pakistan and now with India, particularly since there simply is no evidence of which we are aware or which has been put in the public domain, or even in the private domain, by the US indicating that there was actually EC activity in this Indian market. There was alleged to be a prospective EC activity in Pakistan—and I presume the same point would be made in this case—but there certainly is no actual activity going on. We have a situation of the US announcing this weekend 982,000 tonnes—just on one million tonnes—of wheat sales at a highly subsidised price.
The only ground for comfort in all of this is that the wheat in question is red wheat, not the white wheat that Australia sells.

TALK.START.PARA: —It still forces the price down.

—There is, on that basis, room, at least so far as volumes are concerned, for getting access by Australian wheat. We have already had a sale of 500,000 tonnes a few months ago and another sale is being actively negotiated at the moment.

PARA.TAB: But, as Senator Panizza rightly interjects, there is a potential price depressing effect. It remains to be seen what price depressing effect the sale of red wheat will have on white wheat sales in the Indian market and more generally. But certainly there is legitimate ground for anxiety and for concern about that. I express that concern now, as I have done publicly already—others have done so in prospect before—and as we must continue to do. The difficulty is that the motivation clearly of this sale is far more to do in the present environment with politics in the United States than good trade policy or even legitimate counterassaults on the EC to bring to a head the battle we are all familiar with about export subsidies in the context of international trade generally.

Australia's position remains as put by me last week to the United States, as put by John Kerin a few days earlier, as put by John Dawkins a few days before that, and by all of us on innumerable occasions, that we do regard it as quite intolerable that Australia should be the victim of this cross-fire between the US and the EC.

We do regard it as a deeply unhappy situation that markets which have been either traditional or significant for Australians should be targeted in this way. One cannot say that India has been a traditional market for Australia. It has not been much of a market for anyone for a number of years. It is only periodically when harvests fail and so on that external sales are sought at all. But there has certainly been some wheat to be sold there this year and there is no evidence that the EC has been in there with subsidised wheat. It is the US that has taken the step of putting its own wheat in there on a subsidised basis with all the implications that we are all only too unhappily aware of.

Again, the problem can only be solved in the context of a timely resolution of the Uruguay Round negotiations. That is the only hope that any of us have. We are continuing to work very hard to grab what is left of the small window open to the community in the next two or three weeks, to try to achieve that result.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer but I asked whether he had sought and/or received any assurances from the responsible people in America.

PARA.TAB: The response I got was essentially the same as the one every Australian Minister has had over the last few months.
