Senator Calvert asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 14 September 1992:

(1) Did the former Minister for Resources, Senator Cook give the owner of the southern Tasmanian Benders limestone quarry an official and conclusive assurance in a letter dated 18 August 1988 that the Government had no objection to the continued operation of the Quarry.

(2) On the basis that such an assurance was given, has the decision to close the Quarry been nothing more than further evidence that the Government simply cannot be trusted in any consultation or negotiation and that even a written agreement with this Government such as the Cook/Groom Agreement of November 1988 is not worth the paper it is written on.

(3) If the Minister is prepared to defend his Government's record, will he give an assurance that the Quarry owner, Mr Ray Bender will receive compensation as specified in Clause 16 of the 1988 Cook/Groom Agreement.

(4) Finally, why did the Government conduct meaningless discussions with the Tasmanian State Government on the so called future of the Quarry with the knowledge that it had already arranged for the Proclamation closing the Quarry to be signed secretly by the Governor-General some three weeks before.
Senator Collins—The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) Yes, the letter was prepared on the basis of knowledge of operations of the Quarry at that time. Senator Cook also stated that, `both the Commonwealth and the State would need to be consulted were there any proposals to extend the boundaries of your operation'.

(2) The decision to curtail quarrying at Benders Quarry was based on conclusions reached by two studies commissioned by the Tasmanian Department of Parks, Wildlife and Heritage, Environment and Planning and the Forestry Commission. The Kiernan Report of November 1991 was commissioned to determine the relationship between the Exit Cave karst drainage system and the existing and proposed future boundaries of Benders Quarry. The Tasmanian Department of Environment and Planning undertook an Assessment Report in January 1992 on Benders Pty Ltd proposal for future operations and extensions at the Quarry. Both reports concluded that continued quarrying operations at Benders Quarry are likely to damage the World Heritage values of the Ida Bay karst system.

(3) Legal advice available to me concludes that there is no legal obligation for the Commonwealth to pay compensation under Clause 16 of the Cook/Groom Agreement. Given the express terms of the Agreement, there may be a political commitment to assist Benders Pty Ltd for any closure or relocation. Accordingly, the Commonwealth has offered to negotiate with Benders Pty Ltd an ex-gratia payment for closure of the Quarry of an amount not exceeding the Commonwealth relocation and redundancy offer to Tasmania of $476,000.

(4) The Commonwealth had undertaken discussions and corresponded with the Tasmanian Government on the cessation of quarrying since February 1992. The Prime Minister indicated in a letter of 15 July 1992 to Premier Groom that should the Commonwealth financial offer for relocation of the Quarry continue to prove unacceptable, the Commonwealth would forthwith move by Regulations under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act to prohibit quarrying. Premier Groom had previously advised at a Tasmanian World Heritage Ministerial Council meeting on 8 July 1992 that the Commonwealth financial offer was unacceptable. The Commonwealth received advice in late July that Benders Pty Ltd was drilling holes in preparation for blasting. As the Prime Minister had not received a reply to his letter of 15 July 1992, a Proclamation was signed at a regular Executive Council meeting on 3 August 1992. The Commonwealth was mindful of the need to take prompt action, if required, to protect the World Heritage values of Exit Cave. Although the Proclamation was signed on 3 August 1992 it did not come into operation until 19 August 1992 after further correspondence and negotiations with Tasmania and written advice from Premier Groom on 18 August 1992 that his Government was not prepared to plan for relocation of the Quarry.

ANSWER.PARA: Great Barrier Reef

PARA.TAB: Further to a question asked by Senator Reynolds on 15 September about a major development planned for Trinity Inlet near Cairns, I now provide the following information:
I understand the development referred to in the question is the Royal Reef Resort and Residential Community Development.

The proposed development is well outside the Marine Park and therefore the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has no jurisdiction in this area. However, the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage, which is coordinating an impact assessment study on behalf of the Mulgrave Shire Council, has identified and contacted the Marine Park Authority as an advisory body with an interest in the proposed development. An advisory body has a legal role defined by Queensland legislation.

To date the Authority has given advice on the guidelines for an impact assessment study to be prepared by the proponent and has subsequently commented on those aspects of the study that relate to possible impacts on the Marine Park.

The Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act does not apply because no Commonwealth decision is required for the development. However, the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency has been actively involved in the State assessment study as an advisory body and has also commented on the impact assessment study. This will help to ensure that the State study will satisfy any Commonwealth assessment requirements that might arise in the future.

I understand a comprehensive monitoring program is proposed in the impact assessment study which is to cover both construction and operational phases of the development. The Marine Park Authority will work closely with the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage to ensure that any negative effects to the adjacent marine park are identified.
Motion (by Senator McMullan)—by leave—proposed:
That the following conditions apply to debate on motions relating to answers given to questions without notice for the weeks beginning 6 and 12 October 1992:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a) motions shall relate only to answers given that day to questions without notice;
(b) a senator may speak for not more than four minutes on such a motion;
(c) the total time for debate on all motions relating to answers to questions without notice on any day shall not exceed 30 minutes; and
(d) the time taken in raising and determining any points of order during the debate under this order shall not be regarded as part of the time allowed for debate under this order.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition would have hoped, in light of the experience of the last sitting week when I think the Senate performed much more efficiently than it had done in the past in terms of the conduct of Question Time and the subsequent period of taking note of the answers, that the Government, in moving this motion today following the motion that we dealt with before Question Time, would have had the courtesy, first of all, to discuss the content of its proposals with us and, secondly, to have taken account of the previous debate that occurred on this very similar motion during the last sitting week. That debate revolved around the four points that the Government, through Senator McMullan, has brought forward again today, namely, that the Government is imposing several very severe conditions on its motion to take note of questions and answers after Question Time.

PARA.TAB: The first condition is that it will constrict the consideration of answers only to those given that day. We had a debate on this very matter just three weeks ago. I thought there was a general feeling throughout the chamber that it was at least reasonable that the answers could be those relating to questions asked the preceding day because on occasions often a question cannot be adequately answered and the Minister comes in with further material that day. I might be misunderstanding Senator McMullan, but is he covering—

TALK.START.PARA: —In the way that we agreed with Senator Macdonald last time, it is reflected in this again.

—On that issue, it looks as though we may have a situation which is acceptable to the coalition. We then come to the proposition that each senator be restricted to speaking for four minutes in taking note of a Minister's answer. We had considerable debate on this matter the last time the issue was raised. The situation has since changed. The Government did agree to an amendment by the coalition that the original proposal for two minutes be extended to four minutes. We welcomed that, although at the time we made the point that that was far too short a period of time for consideration of answers that had been given previously.

PARA.TAB: Today, we have the Government sticking with the four-minute proposal despite the fact that we have increased the amount of time that Government Ministers will have to answer questions from four minutes to six minutes. In other words, we have increased the period of time which the Government has available to it to answer questions by 50 per cent—from four minutes to six minutes—yet there is no provision for that to be reflected in the time that Opposition senators can have to take note of those answers.

On behalf of the coalition, I say to the Government that four minutes is a totally unrealistic and unreasonable amount of time. I propose to move that the period of four minutes referred to in the Government's motion be omitted and that it be substituted with a period of six minutes. If Senator McMullan wants to be even Steven with where we were during the week we tried this, I am trying to get the same situation relative to that which we had last time.

The third condition that the Government has imposed is that the total amount of time in which to take note of answers be restricted to 30 minutes. We argued this point in some detail when the matter was considered three weeks ago. At that time the coalition moved an amendment to substitute 60 minutes for 30 minutes. I will not go into all the arguments for that amendment again; they are set out in the Hansard debates of 15 and 16 September.

However, I remind honourable senators that if those opposite restrict the total time in which to take note of answers to questions to 30 minutes they are in effect saying that there will be no time to consider answers to probably more than one-third or one-quarter of the answers that have been given during Question Time. On behalf of the coalition, I propose to move an amendment that the period of 30 minutes be omitted from Senator McMullan's motion and that the period of 60 minutes be substituted. The coalition can accept the fourth point in Senator McMullan's motion, namely, that the time taken for points of order will be omitted from the total time.

I very much hope the Democrats are persuaded by the experience of the trial held in the last week of sittings. It was a very successful trial. I hope the Democrats are persuaded by the arguments that we put at that time, and which we are repeating today, for an extension of the time in which each senator can speak in taking note of an answer from four minutes to six minutes and for an extension of the total time from 30 minutes to 60 minutes. Those are very worthwhile and very necessary amendments to Senator McMullan's motion.

The attitudes and actions of the Democrats on the last occasion this matter arose and their performance earlier today when they moved an amendment to Senator Hill's motion—which, in effect, has very largely wrecked the efficient operating procedures that we had developed in the last sitting week—has shown them once again as being no more than compliant servants of this Government. TALK.START.PARA: —I think the logic just displayed by Senator Coulter explains why the Democrats got only 3 per cent in the Victorian election. We have heard a man who claims to be intelligent say that he is allowing the Government to have its way by leaving unchanged the time limit for comments on motions to take note of a Minister's answer because we need three weeks to test that—but one week was enough to know that two minutes was too short for Ministers to answer questions, with another two for supplementaries; that is, four minutes. That is simply evidence that he belongs, lock, stock and barrel, to the Government—and no doubt we will in time find out what the price of that was.

PARA.TAB: It is really time that people saw what tricks the Democrats get up to. Long have we said that one cannot buy them; one can only rent them by the half hour. Now it seems that one can only rent them for four minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Victorians know that now.

—Yes, they clearly do. What is the purpose of taking note of an answer during Question Time? Why is the practice used and provided for? The answer is, normally, that the answer given by the Minister either is misleading to the public and needs to be dealt with then and there and that 24 hours is too long to go by; or that while the issue is top of mind, while the issue is hot, as it were, it is necessary to set the record straight and to have fair debate on it.

PARA.TAB: If we take a look at some of the issues that have been raised in taking note of an answer, we see things like the Marshall Islands affair; we see things like the questions relating to Ambassador Butler; we see a whole range of issues where it takes longer than the four minutes which are permitted in order to have a full airing of the facts and figures that surround the answer given by the Minister on that day.

Any reading of the Hansard will show that the proper spirit of debate is evidenced in the procedure of taking note of the Minister's answer. There is a fair exchange while people are thinking of the issues; they are not contrived; somebody has not sat down for two hours out in an office and written out a speech—which is supposed to be against our Standing Orders—as the Democrats do on so many occasions. They are the worst offenders. They stand here and read a prepared text on some issue, whereas if they were asked to speak to it in a spontaneous manner they probably could muster only one minute. I am trying to say that putting a limit on Question Time is the same as putting a limit on that necessary procedure for taking note of an answer given at Question Time; and, to my mind, they should not be tied one to the other at all.

The reason we put a time limit on the amount of time that a Minister may take for answering a question is very simply that we were seeing an abuse of process. Question Time is meant to be a time when the Executive is accountable. Time and again we would see a dorothy dixer given to a Minister to propound Opposition policy or to make a statement about something that he wanted to get down without using a proper statement by the Minister—probably too much trouble was involved to do it properly and get it circulated so there could be proper debate on it. So we use the properly provided for ability to take note of an answer—or the pseudo-statement, dare I say, in many cases—so that debate can ensue immediately the Minister has made those statements. There is no relationship at all between the amount of time that ought to be available to debate an important statement that has been made during Question Time and the simple time taken to ask a question and for the initial answer to be given.

So I find this whole debate rather spurious and contrived, but on the last occasion we in the Opposition did agree that we would accept the four-minute level when the two-minute response time was available for Ministers to answer both times—both on the answer and on the supplementary. But for the Democrats to now turn around and say, `Oh, well, you can have only four minutes to take note' when four minutes of answer has just been given just shows what a charade their independence is. It is non-existent. As I said, no doubt time will tell what sort of a deal has been done in order to get the Democrats to agree to what amounts to a gagging of free speech in this chamber.

We have already seen the double-speak of the Minister for incompetence, otherwise known as Minister Bolkus, in his handling of the banning of free speech. When the High Court rules him down and says, `You are not allowed to taken freedom of speech away from Australians', what does he say? He says, `Terrific, I really love that judgment'. My goodness—the Minister for incompetence! That is the sort of thing that should be debated here again and again, and it will be in the MPI this afternoon.

One can get very angry at the way the Government chooses to abuse the processes of this Parliament. Anything that does not suit the Executive's convenience somehow has to be struck down. But the truth of the matter is that it can only be struck down with the concurrence of the Democrats. It looks like they have achieved it again—and they cannot even be bothered to sit here and support Senator Coulter's arguments. As I said, the illogicality of what Senator Coulter had to say in his five-minute contribution surely shows why the Democrats are in decline, why Senator Powell left them and why they got only 3 per cent of the vote in the Victorian election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of my colleague Senator Short, the amendments that he has moved and the remarks of Senator Bishop. It is important that the chamber understand what

SPEECH.PARA: has happened today; it is of quite some significance. There was a deliberate effort by the Senate to improve the quality of Question Time. We ascertained—and I think the public would agree—that the central problem with Question Time was the very long and abusive answers that Ministers gave. As a result, the Senate moved to limit the time which Ministers could take to answer questions.

PARA.TAB: It was not an onerous limit. It had the effect, as we have seen from the four days over which the experiment took place, that the numbers of questions, including supplementaries, were: 34 on the first day, 34 on the second day, and 28 on the third and fourth days. What we saw during that time was quite an increase in the number of people on this side of the chamber putting questions to Ministers.

The Democrats then decided that this experiment, which was widely praised and which substantially lifted the number of questions to the average level that every other government has achieved since 1970, had failed after four days. Senator Coulter of the Australian Democrats had the cheek to get up today and say, `Well, it worked today'. The trouble with Senator Coulter and his colleagues is that they never do the required research. They speak to the Government; they speak to Senator McMullan; but they do not get the key statistics.

The key statistics are shown in this table—and, with the concurrence of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) at the table, I propose to seek incorporation of them. This table shows, for this year, the number of questions which have been asked each day in Question Time. I seek leave now to incorporate that table in the Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: [TABLE OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 1151]

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—I remind Senator Kemp that leave is to be granted by all senators—and by their silence leave is granted—not just by the representative of the Government opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —This table shows that this year during Question Time—which I believe has been progressively abused—the average number of questions which were asked each day was 21.

PARA.TAB: That figure is a bit inflated because there are a number of Question Times in which we expanded the length of Question Time and, of course, it incorporates those four days where we lifted the average very substantially. What that shows is that we are absolutely back to where we were, because today Senator Coulter got up very proudly and said that Question Time was not destroyed because 21 questions were asked and answered. That is exactly what it was like before the new rules were brought in. In one hit Senator Coulter has taken Question Time, which had this remarkable improvement—an improvement which was welcomed by virtually all observers, with the exception of the people on the other side of the chamber—back to the bad old days.

In contrast to some earlier weeks, I think the Government was remarkably disciplined today. Having won this magnificent coup from Senator Coulter, having fooled the Democrats and got their agreement to take Question Time back to the bad old days, Government senators were pretty sensible today. They said, `We will be fairly disciplined'. `Fairly disciplined' means merely answering the same number of questions which they have answered on average for the whole year. It certainly was not their worst day. That is what Senator Coulter has done. With this simple action of his, he has really destroyed after only four days the major initiative of this chamber in decades to improve the quality of Question Time.

Then we come to the next issue. The next major initiative that was taken to try to improve the quality of debate in this chamber, and to try to make Ministers more accountable, was the procedure taken to take note of an answer after Question Time. Again, that was a very important initiative by the Senate chamber in which the real debates could properly occur and Ministers had to stay behind and answer for their administration and account for the answers that they gave in Question Time. There was nothing contrived about taking note of an answer. It was not like the formalised matter of public importance procedure. By and large, it was a very genuine debate; an attempt to make Ministers more accountable to the chamber.

What did Senator Coulter do faced with the next major initiative that was taken? Again he bought the Government's line that the rights of senators should be limited to question and debate the answers that Government Ministers gave. Why Senator Coulter did that is beyond belief to me. I understood that one of the Democrats' major reasons for being here—their raison d'etre—was to try to make governments more honest and more accountable.

Under this new procedure—which I believe was working remarkably well and which, by and large, was not used every day, but was regularly used—the quality of debates which ensued during that period were of value to this chamber and certainly of value to the public at large. Again, Senator Coulter has moved to reduce this major initiative taken by the Senate to make the Executive more accountable. I wait anxiously to hear how any other Democrat can come into this debate. Senator Bourne is in the chamber now and presumably she will vote for this rule. I will be fascinated to hear from her just how this particular initiative will improve the quality of debate and the accountability of Government Ministers in this chamber.

Let me turn to the link which Senator Bishop said she could not quite see; I fully agree. I find the link between Question Time and taking note, and the need to relate the times involved one to the other, as somewhat spurious. The thing which really persuaded Senator Coulter last time was that somehow we had to go to a four-minute limit on the contribution that senators could make in taking note, because Ministers in Question Time were limited to four minutes. If Senator Coulter and Senator Bourne go back to Hansard—and we look forward to Senator Bourne's contribution—they will see that that was the linkage from which they then derived this rule that somehow we should limit senators to four minutes.

Today Senator Coulter said in relation to Question Time, `We want to continue to restrict the time available for Opposition senators to ask questions'. We were quite happy and content to stick with that one minute. I happen to think that, by and large, one minute for most questions is fair enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not with your leader!

—Senator Coulter has had his chance. He really is a terrible dill. He should just control himself. The party that wants to make this chamber and the Government more accountable said, `Let's restrict the rights and the time available to individual senators to question Ministers, but let's expand the time of Ministers to answer those questions'. He has now derived the John Coulter six minute rule.

PARA.TAB: The whole linkage argument which he ran the last time—that we had to relate the four minutes in total that Ministers could answer questions to the four minutes allowed for taking note, which frankly shows how spurious it was—was dropped out entirely.

I hope the public and the press take note of this, that the Australian Democrats—who, as I understand, have been voted by many of their supporters into this chamber to keep governments honest—today have dumped their heritage in a very dramatic way. They have brought to a dead halt in the Senate efforts to reform Question Time and, by continuing to support this other new initiative and procedure after Question Time to take note of answers, which, as I said, requires Ministers to come into this chamber to debate—one of the most important initiatives this chamber has taken for a very long period—the Democrats have again attempted to tightly curtail one of the most important procedures that we have seen in this chamber.

What Senator Coulter has done today was not based on any information. No tables were incorporated in Hansard. There was no reference in Senator Coulter's speech to any statistics. It was based on no research and he had the cheek to get up in this chamber and say what a great Question Time it was today; we are now back to the average of 21 questions which the Government has had for the full year.

I strongly support the remarks of my colleagues Senator Short and Senator Bishop. They have outlined the case particularly well. I totally reject the remarks that Senator Coulter made today. As Senator Loosley knows, the Labor Party likes to say, `Wear the cross'. When the public sees what the Democrats have done to sacrifice their heritage and support this Government in curtailing the rights of Opposition senators to question Ministers, not only the Government but also the Australian Democrats will be severely condemned.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Loosley on this day, relating to Bangladesh.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, made clear in his response to my question, the circumstances which confront the people of the Chittagong Hill Tracts region of Bangladesh have not attracted great publicity in Australia to date, either within our political circles or in terms of the media coverage of foreign affairs. I hope that situation changes, for the circumstances to which I allude deserve far greater attention.

PARA.TAB: We are really talking about very serious human rights concerns that are both legitimate and immediate, and ones which I am pleased to be able to say, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has made clear, have been taken up by Australia through our High Commission in Dhaka. Indeed, it is fair to say that the Australian Government has been particularly diligent in this area, as we have been of recent times in neighbouring Burma.

As the Foreign Minister made abundantly clear, the Bangladeshi security forces have been less than exemplary in the maintenance of peace in the Chittagong Hill Tracts. There have been abuses and very definite identifiable violations of human rights. This is a continuing problem, hence my reason for raising it this afternoon in the Senate.

Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would be aware, Bangladesh is a country that is heavily dependent upon foreign aid for basic services and infrastructure. In this regard, it is reasonable to expect that there will be respect for human rights within Bangladesh as a precondition for the continuing flow of foreign aid. It is quite reasonable for this Parliament to make a linkage between respect for human rights and the continuing flow of Australian aid and Australia's continuing support for participation by Bangladesh within the international aid community and with international aid agencies.

We are entitled to expect better behaviour on the part of the Government of Bangladesh and the security forces of Bangladesh in respect of the Chittagong Hill Tracts. The security forces ought to be able to guarantee rather than threaten the security of the people of the Tracts. Australia's focus on human rights in our region is both established and enduring. It has been effective as our diplomacy has been effective in recent times in the region, examples including APEC and the Cambodian peace process.

I conclude by saying that a foreign policy which is devoid of human rights concerns is a foreign policy so sterile as to be devoid of both values and decency. Australian foreign policy is based on principles of both national interest and international obligation incorporating concern for fundamental human rights. In that regard it is worthy of endorsement and support, including the concerns expressed today in the Parliament over the circumstances that apply in Bangladesh.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Legislation

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Deputy President has received a letter from Senator Parer proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The need for the Senate to:

(1)applaud the finding of the High Court that the political advertising provisions of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Act 1991 are invalid, thus supporting the consistent stand of the Liberal and National Parties in their defence of freedom of speech and democracy in Australia;
(2)condemn the Labor Government and the Democrats for continuing, at great cost, to attack freedom of political expression in Australia for their own self interest; and

(3)condemn the Minister for persisting with legislation which attacked freedom of speech and freedom of political expression and subsequently claiming, when it was found to be unconstitutional, that the decision was a victory for freedom of speech in Australia.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance that we are debating today relates to the rise and fall of the infamous Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991. The recent High Court decision that the ban on political advertising was invalid is a damning indictment not just of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) but of the Executive, the whole Labor Caucus and, with the one exception of Senator Sowada, the Australian Democrats themselves. This whole exercise was best described in the Weekend Australian as one of the most embarrassing policy debacles in almost 10 years of Labor government.

PARA.TAB: It is worth recalling the origins of this infamous piece of paper. The original legislation set out to ban at all times political advertisements on radio and television for all levels of government. In other words, for 365 days a year no political party, political candidate or any third party or individual would have been allowed to place on radio or television an advertisement which in any way could affect the outcome of a future election. That in itself would have amounted to a total blackout.

The original Bill had the tacit support of the Australian Democrats. The Australian Democrats—the left wing socialists who go around beating their breasts about the freedom and rights of individuals—were about to agree to support a Bill to ban political advertising in this country. If it had not been for the campaign waged by the Liberal and National parties, by radio stations and, I might say, by the print media, which had nothing to gain, that is what would have happened. At that time the television stations were not as outgoing, presumably because of rumours that were floating around all over the place that there would be retribution by this Government if they did so. That is the sort of caper, these are the sorts of standover tactics, that this Government is on about.

The Liberal and National parties made it abundantly clear that we would never ever accept this outrageous attack on freedom of speech or political expression but that we would accept disclosure provided that all parties were treated equitably. There were two aspects to the Bill. The Minister thought he was being pretty clever. He put those two aspects together and said, `What we are really trying to do is ban advertising; but what we are really after is disclosure. We will embarrass the Opposition because the Opposition will not support the disclosure requirements'. The rug was pulled right from under them. No matter what the bleatings of Senator Bolkus and the Government were, the Opposition stated categorically that we would support disclosure provided it was fair and equitable.

TALK.START.PARA: —By the way, where is he?
—It is interesting that the Minister is not in the chamber. I will come to him in a minute. He is due for some special treatment.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, wrote to the then Prime Minister and requested that the Bill be split. In other words, he was saying, `Look, we will support disclosure provided it is fair and equitable but never will we support this ban, this attack, on freedom of speech'. This request by Dr Hewson was rejected by the Labor Government. The then Prime Minister was quoted as saying—honourable senators opposite ought to remember these words because the High Court has taken a different view—`Let's teach the kid a lesson'. That is what the then Prime Minister said at the time.

The Minister, quite improperly in my view, hired outside consultancies to keep track of any immediate comments by me and my colleagues such as Senator Kemp and Senator Olsen when he was here. He actually used taxpayers' money—not a few thousand dollars but some hundreds of thousands of dollars—for his own political purposes in order to muzzle the Australian public. As I have said, this was quite an improper use of taxpayers' money.

The aim of the legislation was twofold and blatantly transparent. The Federal Labor Party was broke and the Labor Government, like its collapsed counterparts—let us never forget this—in Russia and Eastern Europe, was prepared to do anything it could to limit criticism of its own past performances: a key reason why it imposed this outrageous legislation.

Of course, the Labor Party was concerned that its past performance would be brought to light either during or before an election campaign by the Liberal Party, the National Party or any other third party. What was and is that performance even today? Because there are numerous examples of that performance, it is impossible to go through the lot. One of the major performances about which the Labor Party can hang its head is the fact that it has consigned over one million Australians to the unemployment scrap heap with no light at the end of the tunnel. What a way for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to `teach the kid a lesson'! That is all he could say: `Let us teach the kid a lesson'.

It has been claimed that the view of the general public was somewhat apathetic. There is a degree of truth in that, but it has always been my belief that the major reason for this apathy was that no Australian citizen could believe that any government would even contemplate bringing in legislation that would remove or limit his or her freedom the way this legislation did. When Senator Olsen, Senator Kemp and myself were going around Australia talking to people, we found them incredulous. The opinion that was coming through was, `We don't believe they will do that'; yet there it was within the legislation.

The Minister claimed that his underlying purpose in bringing forward the legislation was to avert the potential for future corruption. The argument was that the sums of money needed to run political campaigns were becoming so great that inevitably corruption would occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —It did with the Labor Party.

—I am glad Senator Macdonald raised that. He has inspired me to say a few words about that. The report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, Who pays the piper calls the tune, openly stated that there had been no evidence ever of corruption in the Federal scene. Anyone would know that if there is corruption there is no way in the world it will be fixed by legislation.

PARA.TAB: At no time during this debate was any mention made by Senator Bolkus or the Labor Party that the real corruption that exists as far as the Labor Party is concerned is the stranglehold exercised upon it by that unelected group, the leaders of the trade union movement. These are the real people who determine who gets preselected by the Labor Party and who stays preselected. If no-one believes me they should ask ex-Senator John Black who I saw in this building just a few days ago. He was waffled out of this place by the AWU and the left wing of the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —He went down the greasy pole.

—Obviously that is where the title `Down the greasy pole' came from. I had not thought about that. Of course, a man of greater standing got preselected—Senator Burns got preselected ahead of John Black. These are the people whose approval must be sought and obtained before the Government makes any decision, significant or otherwise. I hope Senator Aulich, who is in the Chair, forgives me, but I presume he fell victim to a similar situation.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal and National parties called for a Senate select committee inquiry during the 1991 winter recess because we were so concerned about the effect the Bill would have on freedom of speech. This attempt was rejected. In fact, I moved a notice of motion in this place before the winter recess to refer this Bill to a committee. It was rejected by the Labor Party and, I might say, the Democrats, who should hang their heads in shame over this whole sorry episode.

The confident attitude of the Minister and the reaction we had from discussions with the Democrats were such that it was plainly obvious that a deal, a compromise, call it whatever one likes, had been made. Because we expressed that concern, people in society who until that stage had supported the Democrats also expressed concern. That was one of the reasons why Senator Powell found herself `a talking head', if I might use that expression which came out of the legislation, and lost her political head to Senator Coulter. The expectation then was that that having occurred maybe, just maybe, the Democrats would go back to accepting their responsibilities and acting on behalf of those people in Australia who treasure their freedom and democracy.

The Liberal and National parties held their own inquiry, and I would particularly like to pay tribute to ex-Senator John Olsen who was given the task of chairing that inquiry. All those who gave evidence and those who contributed—from the Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin, Professor Flint of the Press Council, Professors Alston, Zines, Walker, Gilbert, Henningham and a host of others—were implacably opposed in their evidence to the attack on free speech in this particular legislation. Out of it came the question as to whether the Bill, if enacted, would be constitutional.

I want to talk about this briefly. In answer to my question today in the Senate, Senator Bolkus said that no-one would have imagined that freedom of speech would have been accepted by the High Court as a way of invalidating this Bill. He also went on to say that nowhere in debate was constitutional validity raised. Nothing could be further from the truth. It was out of that committee and at a public hearing in this very place that Professor Alston said he thought there were constitutional problems. Subsequently, Professor Zines also came out and said there were constitutional problems. This was ignored by the Government.

Eventually, we did get a select committee and, again, the evidence overwhelmingly was against the contents of this Bill. This did not faze, however, the Labor members of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures and, of course, they supported the Bill; thus in the process making a farce of these types of inquiries.

The Bill, when debated, resulted in the longest continuous sitting of the Senate since 1964. It was not an engineered filibuster. Those who spoke on the coalition side were genuinely concerned about this atrocious legislation. It was then up to the New South Wales Government and the television stations to take the matter to the High Court. Its decision is a landmark decision as it held that the broadcast ban was invalid because it attacked the doctrine of representative government. That is the reason.

The most extraordinary response—breathtaking in its sheer hypocrisy—came from the Minister. Here was a Minister who with the support of his Executive, the Labor Caucus and the Democrats, had connived to limit the freedom of political expression in Australia. He failed because of the High Court decision. He then had the temerity and audacity to claim it as a victory for freedom of speech in Australia. What an extraordinary statement! The hypocrisy is totally and utterly breathtaking.

To claim that the decision is broader than the doctrine of representative government is drawing a long bow and is a mechanism which the Minister has attempted to use to save face. It is a story which the media has not swallowed. In my reading of the judgment, it was apparent that the Chief Justice went to some lengths to quarantine the decision.

One senior Minister was quoted as saying, `Nick should not have to carry the burden of the High Court on his own', and I agree. The burden of this embarrassing defeat should be shared. Bob Hogg, who initiated the legislation, the Prime Minister, the Labor Executive, the Labor Caucus and the Democrats are the crowd who connived to attack a basic freedom in Australia which is the cornerstone of our democracy. It is the same crowd who have been responsible for record interest rates, record bankruptcies and record unemployment.

This Labor Government has had the same pyrrhic victory with the ban on advertising as it had with the economy. In the first instance, the Labor Party was thrown out by the High Court and, in the second instance, it will be thrown out by the Australian people whenever an election is called.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an article in the Australian Financial Review of yesterday which probably sums up the situation we are in, and not without a touch of irony. Anne Flahvine, who is a legal reporter, Sydney based journalist and law graduate, starts off a feature piece with these three paragraphs :

SPEECH.PARA: If Lionel Murphy were alive today, he'd be entitled to a wry smile. For years, Murphy was a lone voice on the High Court arguing that fundamental rights—including the right of free speech—could be implied from the Constitution.

PARA.TAB: Just one hour before he died in 1986, Murphy's judicial colleagues sounded what was thought to be the death knell to this argument when they rejected out of hand the submission that there was an implied constitutional guarantee of freedom of communication.
Six years later, they've changed their minds. And not only in relation to free speech.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a touch of irony here. Some six years and a few months ago I spent some time with Lionel Murphy. One of the issues that we discussed, as he was being chased off the High Court, was this very issue. We shared a frustration that the concept that he was pursuing at the time was not getting support, was not being accepted. So there is irony in the fact that, some six years later, the High Court has now chosen to basically embrace the philosophy of Justice Murphy in this area.

PARA.TAB: There are some basic propositions in this debate—as I say, the sands have changed—that need to be placed on the record at the start. Firstly, there is one party in this Parliament that has been concerned with human rights. Secondly, there is one party in this Parliament that has been consistently opposed to human rights. Thirdly, this Government acted in accordance with international responses to this problem. Fourthly, the High Court surprised everybody. Senator Parer may drag out bits and pieces now, but former Premier Greiner, when launching the challenge and when asked about its chances, said in pretty straight terms, `It's a punter's chance—probably odds against'.

The concept of freedom of political communication which has been embraced by the High Court was nowhere near the lips of anyone in the debate at that time or previous to it. There is another basic proposition in this debate. Basically, a concept of rights in the Constitution is something that those on the other side has not wanted. It will come back to bite them at some stage.

Peter Costello, the shadow Attorney-General, has made comments in recent days which indicate that he, at least, understands the dimension of the High Court decision. Although I do not agree with those comments—I will go to them later—I think it is fairly well balanced to say that a High Court acting in this way offers major challenges to the sort of legislation that Hewson and Howard, for instance, would want to implement in the industrial relations area. It offers huge problems in terms of any agenda that the Opposition may want to put in place. In essence, the Opposition may have won a particular battle but a long fought out war about a Bill of Rights is something that it has not won.

It is a surprising decision. The result surprised a number of people. But the underlying thinking of the High Court, and the underlying philosophy and principles adopted by the judges—no matter which judge one is talking about—are fairly well described as a fundamental shift in High Court direction on this issue.As I said, Nick Greiner at the time said it was a punter's chance—odds against. For some five years while this issue was debated in this place, in the House of Representatives, in the community and through two committees, the concept of freedom of political communication was never mentioned. So it was surprising in that sense as well.
It is also surprising in terms of international comparisons. Justice Brennan, on pages 35 and 36 of his judgment, goes through some of those international comparisons. He says on page 35:

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the countries which ban paid political advertising during election times have constitutions guaranteeing the right to freedom of expression.

He then goes on to quite accurately document the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. He refers to the European Commission of Human Rights on page 35 in his judgment where it held:
. . . the freedom guaranteed by Art. 10—
which is freedom of expression—

"cannot be taken to include a general and unfettered right for any private citizen or organisation to have access to broadcasting time on radio and television in order to forward its opinion". It held that the recognition of a State's power to license broadcasting and television permitted the granting of licences which excluded political advertising.

So as well as all those points I have made about there having been a surprise to us in this process, there have been international definitions of freedom of expression which have allowed for interventions and intrusions into the general concept of freedom of expression. Justice Brennan goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: It can hardly be doubted that reduction in the cost of effective participation in an election campaign reduces one of the chief impediments to political democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: If one needed more information in terms of international comparisons, he cites the United Kingdom, where there is a ban on buying advertising time on radio and TV. In defending that ban, in about 1971 the UK Government advised the European Commission of Human Rights that the ban:

. . . served `to prevent the exponents of political views with the longest purse—whoever these may be—from having an advantage in terms of buying time on television to promote their cause'. If the clause did not exist, less well endowed parties or movements would have great difficulty in maintaining their point of view in the fact of massive purchase of advertising time by their opponents.

So it is a surprising new concept, one not anticipated even by the then Premier of New South Wales, Nick Greiner, at the time. If you look at the international comparisons, you find that there was enough sustenance for this Government's position.

PARA.TAB: The judgment of the High Court is not without some degree of irony because those on the other side have opposed entrenching in our Constitution a Bill of Rights or the concepts of freedom. But in this decision the High Court has entrenched the freedom of political communication in our law. But not only does it do that; Justice Gaudron and, later, Justice Toohey have given signals that the High Court would contemplate going even further. The sorts of rights that they might be entertaining are those that have been marked out very definitely by Justice John Toohey in a speech he gave in Darwin to a constitutional convention last weekend. One particular paragraph is worth repeating. He said in his speech:

SPEECH.PARA: In that sense, an implied `Bill of Rights' might be constructed. (The common-law rights that might be expected in an implied Bill of Rights would be such things as freedom of speech, assembly and religion; freedom from search and seizure without a warrant based on sworn evidence and stating what can be searched and seized; freedom from arbitrary arrest; freedom from confiscation of property without compensation; no torture or other cruel or unusual punishment; and a right to trial by jury for serious crimes.)

So we have a signal from the High Court judges that they probably expect that they will be asked to address other rights in terms of their role not only in regard to the Constitution but in regard to the general body of law that underpins the constitutional system in this country. The major irony for me is that a concept tossed in by Justice Lionel Murphy was tossed out some six years ago.

PARA.TAB: But it does not end there in terms of ironies. Last week, Peter Costello, fearing that this decision opens the door to an activist role for the High Court, responded by saying that in the future we might have to give more parliamentary scrutiny to the appointment of High Court judges. As the office of my colleague Mr Duffy was quoted as saying last week, Costello's comments were a potential threat to the independence of the judiciary. The fact that he responds to a decision such as this by saying that we may have to pay more attention and give more parliamentary scrutiny to whom we appoint to the High Court is expressing a fear on his part that the High Court will and could work in a way that his side of politics would find unacceptable. We on our side would not attempt to politicise the Bench or muzzle the judges. As I indicated last week, the High Court made a decision; we had to cop it, and we do cop it.

I have been accused of being hypocritical. If one wants to assess where hypocrisy lies in this debate, let us look at the record and let us look where this allegation of hypocrisy should rightfully land. In this matter of public importance, we are asked to:

SPEECH.PARA: Applaud . . . the consistent stand of the Liberal and National Parties in their defence of free speech. . .

It was the Whitlam Government which signed the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. After a number of years of resistance in this country, it was ratified by the Fraser Government. That is the record of the Opposition; that was its role and that is where its commitment to civil liberties starts and ends.

PARA.TAB: A Bill of Rights was put up in this place by Senator Evans; it was opposed stridently by the Opposition. The Opposition opposed the enshrining of rights in our Constitution. A few years later we came back with constitutional amendments to embody in our Constitution a series of rights—the sorts of rights that Justice Gaudron and Justice Toohey talk about in their judgments: the right of one vote one value, the right to vote, freedom of religion, trial by jury and fair compensation for acquisition of property. Those rights were proposed by a bipartisan committee which included Sir Rupert Hamer, a former Premier of Victoria, on the other side of politics. But the Opposition stridently fought against enshrining those rights in our Constitution.

In its decision last week the High Court signalled that the coalition's long term opposition to rights in the Constitution may in fact fail. Why was there opposition to enshrinement in the Constitution of civil rights? Senator Boswell is amongst those who today would want to vote in support of enshrinement of rights. On 5 November 1985, Senator Boswell stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill of Rights . . . will depend on an international covenant to dictate the rights of every Australian. We will not be introducing an international covenant as an Australian law.

He opposed it. Senator Harradine said it would not create another job, but that is neither here nor there. In February 1986, Senator Boswell said he would maintain a campaign. Senator Durack made this matter very clear on behalf of the Opposition, as Opposition spokesperson in this area, when he said in February 1986:
. . . we will not join in an international covenant to bring human rights to everybody.
In February 1986, Brian Archer stated:
This legislation [the Bill of Rights] is, undoubtedly, designed to ensure that crooks get the best end of the law.
He further stated:
I hope that we can destroy the legislation for good and all.

This is the sort of history we are confronted with by those who are throwing the accusation of hypocrisy. One would think that those opposite would have gone through some sort of conversion in this process and that maybe they do now adopt and support the principle of human rights and civil liberties. The one body that opposed what I was doing—and which the Opposition latched onto like velcro—was the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. What do honourable senators reckon the Opposition wants to do to that body? It wanted to abolish it until a few months ago. Now Opposition senators will not abolish it; they will maintain it, but they will cut back $4m of its funding. The Commission used to be allocated $6m a year. Quite recently it was given the function of overseeing privacy legislation and was granted an extra $3m to do that. So it has a budget of $9m. Initially it had a budget of $6m to pursue civil rights issues. The Opposition is going to cut $4m out of the $6m—or out of the $9m if one wants to be generous to it. That is a gutting of HREOC. That is the Opposition's continual response to civil liberties in this country. It does not just end there.

PARA.TAB: The other organisation which we have in Government to keep us in contact with international civil rights and human rights mechanisms is the international law division of the Attorney-General's Department. The Opposition is going to shut that right up. It is going to shift the functions to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. It is going to shut up the mechanism in the Attorney-General's Department that keeps us in contact with international civil rights and it is going to gut HREOC. That is its response. It does not just end there.

One can look at what the Opposition is going to do with legal aid. There is nothing more basic in our society than access to law, but there will be a $10m cutback there. There will be a $17m cutback in the administration of justice. Let us not even think about getting into the area of basic rights of sole parents, migrants and Aboriginals. This is the commitment that those on the other side spell out very loudly. This is the promise that they stand on—

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is only money, why don't you put in a little bit and make legal aid more available?

—Senator Macdonald says that it is only money. If those opposite were running an organisation with a $6m budget and someone took $4m out of its back pocket, there is not much they could do. The Opposition is gutting that organisation. That is the Opposition's promise to this country in the area of civil liberties. The Government's initiatives in this area were guided by a number of factors—to clean up the political environment and to level the playing field. I do not have to go into those areas in great depth.

PARA.TAB: As to allegations that the Government is taking this action basically to ensure the survival of the Labor Party, I say that it was Porky Everingham on 9 July who wrote an article headed, `Broke Libs go Begging for Money'. If the Liberal Party and the Labor Party are stretched for funds to stay in the political process—and we all are, that is undisputed now; it is not just one side of politics—what chance do the minor parties have? What chance do the voices outside have? What chance do the Independents have?

The weekend press is littered with comments from Independents saying they just could not afford to keep up with the major parties in the Victorian election. If we are talking about access to the process, we really have to look at the inequity that is put in place—the latter twentieth century property franchise that is put in place—by the need to have funds to keep one's voice heard. We do not want a Ross Perot manipulating the process in Australia; that is why we took a measure such as this.

I will accelerate through the last part of my contribution here this evening. As to the undemocratic situation we find ourselves in, it was Barry Goldwater—of all people—in the United States who said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not the people but the managed interests who are setting the nation's political agenda and are influencing the position of candidates on important issues of the day.

That is precisely what the Government said when it introduced this legislation and they are precisely the sentiments that have been reflected in some of Justice Brennan's thoughts in his judgment in the High Court. We were not just focussing on the level playing field; concern has been evidenced in ICAC reports and Fitzgerald reports and in WA and elsewhere about this undue influence in the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you keep your job after such a monumental stuff-up?

—Senator Macdonald, with a latter day knowledge, claims it was a stuff-up. During the whole five years of this debate, this Government has been motivated by an intention to clean up this process, and we acted in that way. For five years, nowhere in the debate was the concept of freedom of political expression ever envisaged by anybody. For five years, the constitutional question that has been raised in latter days was not raised until the final days of the debate. It was raised by Premier Greiner who said it was an outside punter's chance, odds against, that they would get up.

PARA.TAB: I will not go into the decision of the High Court in much depth at the moment. All I will say at this stage is that we do have in the Constitution a new unexpected, unforeseen principle and no-one can deny that. It is not the first time the High Court has struck down a piece of legislation and it will not be the last. I will finish on what Michael Gawenda wrote in Time magazine on 13 May 1991, because this will be the lasting thought on this debate:

But in the end, this is a counsel of despair. Some time soon, governments must do something about an electoral system in which, increasingly, money decides who is and who is not heard. Ultimately this renders meaningless the right of free speech, which is one of liberal democracy's central features.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President—
—This will be good.

—Yes. I would like to start by reflecting on the role of the High Court. The High Court is the umpire, the sole arbiter of Commonwealth constitutional matters—and we accept that. One alternative would be to have one of the great ideas of the Young Liberals—a privatised judiciary. Another alternative would be to have the American system of an elected judiciary. I think our system is preferable to those, but that does not mean to say that the High Court is above criticism.

PARA.TAB: I found the logic of parts of the High Court decision quite inconsistent. The High Court said, `Yes, it's okay, the Commonwealth has power to make laws on elections; yes, the Commonwealth has the power to make laws over broadcasting; but it does not have the power to make laws over the broadcasting of electoral advertising material'. Four of the seven High Court judges ruled that the advertising ban should be totally struck out while two others rejected just part of the legislation. Six of the judges acknowledged that there was an implied right of free speech—not just any absolute free speech but the `freedom to discuss and debate political and public affairs'.

I welcome confirmation that there are implied human rights in our Constitution. It is not a cause that the Opposition has championed in the past. I recall that it was extremely critical of Justice Murphy over the many years that he championed this cause. But it does seem to be rather selective to say that the right to discuss and debate political and public affairs is more important than perhaps freedom of assembly and association, freedom of movement, the rights of a person charged with a criminal offence, the protection of individual privacy—in other words, what one might expect to find in a Bill of Rights.

Can we expect the new champions of human rights in Australia—the Party that was going to abolish the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission—to extend their passion for one implied freedom to other equally important freedoms? What did the Liberals say about a Bill of Rights? They opposed it. In opposing the Bill of Rights, in not seeking to improve it by amending it, they opposed many specific rights of Australians. They opposed the right to privacy and the rights of children for which the Bill provided. In voting against a Bill of Rights, in choosing not to improve it by amending it, they opposed the right to trial by jury, to due process and the legislated right to freedom of religion. On 17 February 1986 Senator Knowles said:

SPEECH.PARA: Article 7, enshrining freedom of expression and the imparting of ideas and information of any kind and in any form—
just freedom of speech, freedom of expression—
could be dynamite in Australia's school classrooms. It is not hard to imagine that this Article—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have we not got freedom of speech, you silly galah?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! Senators Knowles, I think you had better withdraw that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Silly galah?
—`Silly galah' is not appropriate; it is not parliamentary.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, could I just seek a ruling from you on that?
—Yes, I have given a ruling. Please withdraw it.
—If `dog's vomit' from the Prime Minister and `sleazebag' and everything else is unparliamentary, I will withdraw `silly galah'.

—Senator Knowles, take your seat. I accept that as an unqualified withdrawal. What the Prime Minister or anyone else says in the House of Representatives is irrelevant to this chamber. While I am in this chair, those words will not be used.
—That is a good precedent. Whacko, we have got that one. We will make a note of that one.
—Order, Senator Knowles!
—That is a good precedent.
—Senator Knowles!
—I am not talking to you; I am talking to Senator Vanstone. You are not trying to gag me, surely.
—I was quoting Senator Knowles and I was reminding us of what she said in 1986 about enshrining freedom of expression in a Bill of Rights. She said that such an Article:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . could justify a teacher expounding an extremist ideology or even a perverted mode of behaviour against the wishes of education authorities or, more particularly, against the wishes of parents.
