TALK.START.PARA: —Australians.

—It is not an absolute. How can we believe the Opposition's new found zeal? The Opposition's record clearly is opposed to human rights. For example, the Opposition believes that workers should not have the right to be protected by minimum award conditions; that is, workers should not have the right not to be exploited by their terms of employment. Clearly, most employers in Australia are not ogres but some are.

PARA.TAB: When discussing the Opposition's record on protecting human rights we must remember before the referendum in 1988 the absolutely disgraceful conduct of Mr Peter Reith in using his free speech to conduct what I consider perhaps the worst propaganda campaign in Australian politics to oppose a constitutional change to guarantee some basic human rights. A major political party in this country actively campaigned against religious freedom, against fair elections and against the right to trial by jury—and the list goes on.

How did the Liberals vote on truth in political advertising? They voted against it. How hypocritical of them to call themselves the defenders of free speech and democracy in Australia. Where do the Liberals stand on the nexus between democracy and money? To the Liberal Party, freedom of speech equals freedom for those who can afford to pay for that speech to be broadcast. This is encapsulated by a cartoon I think in the Canberra Times which shows men from FACTS, the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Services, with dollar signs in their eyeballs saying with glee, `Just exactly how much free speech would you like to buy?'. In this country, unfortunately, as in America, paid free speech and political power are too closely linked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look who had dollar signs in her eyes—a $2m bribe from the Labor Party to put your grubby little party on television.

—Order! Senator Macdonald, you have been continuously interjecting through this speech. Senator Kernot has in fact directed all her remarks through the Chair, as is the proper way to speak in this chamber. Please do not interrupt her again.

—I was developing the point of the nexus between free speech and money, and I was about to quote from The Best Congress Money Can Buy. The central theme of this book is that money determines far too much in American politics today. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Far too often, money determines who shall run for office.
All too often, money determines what messages will be most forcefully conveyed.
Much too often, money is a preoccupation (or an obsession) in the minds of lawmakers.
Yet that prime determinant, money, is a poor tool of democracy, for money is indifferent to truth and to justice, since it is, essentially, unjustly distributed.
That is the point. It is precisely this unjust distribution which makes a mockery of this defence of the absolute freedom of speech. Anatole France in the late nineteenth century said:
The law, in its majestic equality, permits the rich as well as the poor to sleep under bridges, to beg in the streets, and to steal bread.
Judge J. Skelly Wright, in reflecting on that after observing American election campaigns, felt that Anatole France might well have written:

The law, in its majestic equality, allows the poor as well as the rich to form political action committees, to purchase the most sophisticated polling, media, and direct mail techniques, and to drown out each other's voices by overwhelming expenditures in political campaigns.
We know that that does not happen. We know about the financial inequity of campaigning. Judge Wright concluded by saying:
Financial inequities pose a pervasive and growing threat to the principle of "one person, one vote" and undermine the political proposition to which this nation is dedicated—
that is America, and I would hope Australia—
that all men are created equal.

TALK.START.PARA: —And women.

—I was quoting. So what did the champions of freedom of speech and democracy do with this newly confirmed right? Let us look at what they did in Queensland. They used the so-called freedom of speech to abuse the rights of others. They ran what even the Federal Liberal Party backed away from—a particularly sleazy law and order campaign. In this campaign they reflected upon the rights of others and they were deceitful.
—Totally incapable of addressing the subject.
—Oh, keep quiet!
—Why don't you go back to your little telephone box?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! This is the second time that Senator Knowles has needed to be pulled up. In fact, she is transgressing freedom of speech in this chamber. Senator Kernot has in fact got the call. I am calling her now and I do not want any more interruptions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal ads attempted to convey the view that the position with respect to parole policy under a conservative government which had put it in place was different from the policy under the present Queensland Labor Government. It was implied that it was the Queensland Labor Government's fault that a person had committed a murder. The advertising campaign totally exploited a human tragedy and abused the rights of this person's wife and child, and also any right to appeal that he may have had at the time.

PARA.TAB: In Victoria they ran the same sort of campaign, abusing the rights of others and being deceitful. I will quote what Mr Shane Bourke—a local councillor who won more than 16 per cent of the primary vote—had to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It was a disgrace: trickery, blatant lies. It's not fair that they can spend hundreds of thousands of dollars lying.

Despite the fact that he had a how-to-vote card, which showed how to give preferences to either the Liberal Party or the Labor Party, the Liberal Party's advertising campaign pretended that the preferences were being directed to the Labor Party. They used that scare tactic to frighten voters away, voters who do not understand the value of the preferential system and the flow-on of second preferences.

PARA.TAB: Freedom of speech equals a licence to lie for members of the Liberal Party. It is okay to compel commercial operators to tell the truth about a product they want to sell, but it is not okay for politicians to tell the truth about the product they want to sell to the electors, and by that I mean the policies that people have to choose between. We give ourselves the freedom to make untrue and misleading statements and we protect ourselves from that sort of scrutiny.

The Opposition says the community has a right to be bombarded with selective propaganda in the name of free speech. We say that electors have the right to true and accurate information about policies and issues that concern them during an election. Anything less than that is not in the spirit of free speech.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me put on the record yet again, despite the persistent interjections, that it is not a matter of self-interest. It is a passionate view. We have to find a fair balance between a healthy, informed democracy and the political power of those with the most money. I cannot agree that limiting the freedom to discuss and debate political and public affairs for a period of 28 days out of 365 severely impedes freedom of political speech.

PARA.TAB: I do not want us to go down the American track and I, for one, will not be dragged down it without raising my voice in protest. In 10 years time I will be happy if people consult the record and say that the Democrats, amongst others, attempted to save this country from the sleazy, gutter politics so characterising the American political system. We deserve more than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Sleazy, gutter politics' was Senator Kernot's concluding sentence—
—Who wrote it?

—I raise a point of order. An accusation was just made across the chamber by Senator Macdonald that I wrote Senator Kernot's speech. I did not and he should be made to withdraw that remark. There is absolutely no basis on which he can make that allegation.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! There is no point of order, but Senator Bolkus has the position on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot's speech was so bad that I do not think that even Senator Bolkus could have written something as bad as that. `Sleazy, gutter politics' was the concluding sentence of Senator Kernot's speech. One would have thought that the embarrassment that Senator Kernot showed during her speech was justly merited, because the party which was elected to protect people's rights and designed to keep people honest has effectively been censored by the High Court as attempting to join with the Government to prevent freedom of speech.

PARA.TAB: As I said earlier today, how far the new Democrats have come from the old Democrats. Janine Haines and former Senator Don Chipp would not have had a bar of this attempt by the Democrats to ban political advertising, and they said it. Senator Kernot has joined in this new trend of the Australian Democrats. It is an authoritarian streak which we saw today in this chamber when Senator Kernot joined with her colleagues to limit the rights of senators to question Government Ministers.

Senator Kernot is right to be embarrassed, because she has been found out. As Senator Macdonald pointed out in his interjections in this chamber, under this Bill the Democrats were giving themselves a massive $2m benefit and were preventing other independents whom Senator Kernot was supporting from having the right to political advertising.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—That is what Senator Kernot was doing. Above all people, she received a great benefit from this Bill and now her sour grapes or spleen can be explained by the fact that she has lost that benefit. Along with her colleagues, she has also lost any element of principle. Senator Kernot is now walking out of the chamber, because as usual when there is a contrary argument the Democrats do not want to hear. These are the people who constantly support freedom of speech.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, a nasty authoritarian streak is appearing in the political process in this country. We have seen it particularly manifesting itself in this Bill to ban political advertising. If Senator Schacht, Senator Bolkus and Senator Kernot were fair dinkum and worried about the costs of elections and the rights of independents to put their views, they would not be banning political advertising; they would be banning direct mail. Direct mail is the most effective but costly form of political campaigning at the present time. It is only accessible to the major parties who have the resources to conduct this comparatively new form of campaigning.

Basically, if we wanted to test the logic and sincerity of Senator Kernot and Senator Bolkus, we would have seen them arguing against direct mail. I am one who thinks there are elements in political advertising which can cause problems, but at least we have the right to respond publicly and quickly. Whatever the faults of political advertising, they are writ large in the process of direct mail. Of course, Senator Kernot was caught out very recently with her direct mail to the farm machinery producers. She conveyed to them what we believe to be grossly misleading information and she came into this chamber and attempted to justify it. Of course, Senator Kernot was once again found out.

There is probably one aspect of Senator Bolkus's speech with which I did concur and that is that this whole debate is replete with ironies. It was an irony that Senator Bolkus urged us in this chamber to listen to the Human Rights Commission and to retain the Human Rights Commission, which we are doing. But Senator Bolkus ignored the advice of the Human Rights Commissioner. One really wonders how committed Senator Bolkus is to the Human Rights Commission when in probably the most controversial action the Human Rights Commission has been involved in, in relation to political advertising, the Government assiduously ignored its advice.

Then Senator Bolkus came in and said that other countries that have a bill of rights ban political advertising. I guess the real reason a lot of people in this Parliament were very concerned about the Bill of Rights issue when it was debated was that Senator Bolkus said in his own speech that a bill of rights in effect does not protect freedoms and freedoms of speech. As I said, he pointed to countries that have a bill of rights and where the freedom of speech in relation to political advertising is banned.

One can understand the embarrassment of Senator Bolkus at an article which I believe summed up the feelings of many people in the community. The article by Peter Wilson in the Australian pointed to the gross mishandling of this Bill and stated that it was perhaps the most embarrassing bungle in a long history of bungles by this Government. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Supporters of the 42-year-old South Australian left winger argued this week that he should not shoulder all the blame and, to be fair, there were a few hands on the steering wheel.
That is true, and two of the hands on the steering wheel were those of Senator Chris Schacht and Senator John Faulkner.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht regularly comes into this chamber and talks about human rights. I do not entirely doubt the sincerity of Senator Schacht on human rights; he has made the subject a special interest of his. But in the end I guess real commitment to human rights is shown by how committed one is when the views actually conflict with the policy of one's party. That is when one is really tested. One can go overseas and lecture to the South Africans, lecture to the Chinese, go around the world and tell them what you think they should be doing. But the question is: how does one act when human rights issues conflict with the narrow interests of one's own political party?

I have to say that Senator Schacht has been tested in relation to political advertising. It is not that he expressed concern in the party room and then generally removed himself from this debate, as I guess often happens on both sides when members find themselves in conflict with their parties. Senator Schacht, as Chairman of the Select Committee that examined the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, took the lead role in trying to ram this legislation through. He, along with Senator Bolkus, was one of the driving forces behind the Bill. Indeed, it is a great irony—I do not think it will be forgotten in this chamber—that when Senator Schacht, who has at times spoken some sense on human rights issues, was tested and when his hand was put to the fire, he decided to be one of the Bill's great promoters.

I think there are some concerns about the behaviour and the judgments in recent years of the High Court. Senator Bolkus raised that point. I happen to think on this particular issue that the court got it right, but I would not want it to be thought that a lot of people are not looking closely at the activities and judgments of the High Court. Time, as Senator Bolkus said, will show just how this new decision works through. Maybe it will work in surprising ways. Maybe it will end the rights of the closed shop. Maybe it will enable workers to exercise true freedom of choice in deciding whether to join a trade union or not. So I think quite a few freedoms will be tested, and undoubtedly we will be watching the High Court closely to see how it works itself through these judgments.

Senator Bolkus said that no-one expected this legislation to be thrown out. I refer him to the evidence that was presented to the Select Committee. I think it would be ungracious of me not to mention the contributions that my colleague Senator Macdonald made on this important issue. In this chamber on Tuesday 3 December, Senator Macdonald on a number of occasions alerted us to the fact that the legislation was liable to be found to be unconstitutional. It did not come as a surprise to many people. It might have come as a surprise to Senator Bolkus, but that may reflect his capacities as a lawyer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to contribute briefly to this debate to point out some inadequacies in the arguments of Government members in their embarrassed squirming to get out of their present position. What we find is a Minister who came into this place in April and August of last year and tried to tell us that the expression `freedom of speech' means that speech which is not bought. This notion was laughable. It was laughed at by the entire Attorney-General's Department when it was put to it, and it was laughed at by most serious commentators on this issue.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) has displayed in his speech tonight that he either has no capacity to think for himself about the substance of these issues, or that his embarrassment at having failed in this project of limiting freedom of speech in Australia has occasioned him not to say what he really thinks.

Senator Bolkus in his speech said that there are four things we should know. He said we should know that there is one party that supports human rights—I suppose he thinks that is his Party—and one party that is against them. I suppose he would like to paint that as being the Liberal and National parties. Then he says that everything the Government has done is in accord with international responses. In other words, the Government has done only what everyone else does. The fourth thing the Minister said in his speech was that this move by the High Court was a surprise.

The Minister is wrong on all four counts. The Labor Party does have a proud record in relation to human rights issues. I do not deny that and I do not know that anyone else does. It is a proud record marred only, I might say, by a very black spot put on it by Senator Bolkus in seeking to limit freedom of speech in this country. Nonetheless, I do not deny that, other than for that black spot, the Government has a very proud record. I think it is uncharitable of the Minister to suggest that my Party does not have a similar record. We might say that these rights should be protected in different ways, but we do not say that they should not exist or be protected in no way at all.

As to the argument `We have only done what is in accord with international responses', why do we not give away the whole system of responsible government? Why do we not just do a survey of what other countries are doing and follow suit? It is a ludicrous argument. It is ludicrous for a Minister of a government to come in here and say, `We have done what everyone else has done'. Why do the people in the galleries pay our salaries if they only want us to do what everyone else does? We could run the country by survey. Would that be a good idea? Of course not. The expectation is that we will look at what other people do, decide for ourselves whether it is a good idea and articulate substantive reasons as to why it is a good idea. That other people are doing it is not a substantive reason. That is the lemmings to the cliff face argument.

As to the technical legal reasoning of the decision of the High Court, some may think that it is a surprise, but I draw the Minister's attention to a speech I made in August of last year which drew his attention to the Murphy judgment on the Ansett Transport Industries case. Murphy said that there needed to be freedom in relation to speech and other communication, `not only between the States, but in and between every part of the Commonwealth'. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: From these provisions and from the concept of the Commonwealth arises an implication of a constitutional guarantee of such freedoms, freedoms so elementary that it was not necessary to mention them in the Constitution.

Senator Bolkus thinks that in some ironical way, the High Court has now returned to a position more closely aligned with former Senator Murphy than it was at the time. I do not think that is ironical at all. That is what the legal system and the High Court is all about. Law is always developing with people changing their minds, moving on, et cetera. These things are not meant to be set in concrete. The law is meant to develop as is our understanding of it, just as society develops.

PARA.TAB: The Minister says, `Watch out with your industrial relations reforms or you'll be in trouble'. I look forward to a greater elucidation from the court as to what it thinks these powers or implied or assumed rights are. Nothing pleases me more than a greater test of the constitutional limitations that we live under. That is what the High Court is there for, and I do not walk away from that. If the Minister thinks that that is a problem, he has a different view from mine.

Basically, the Minister said that the concept of a right to freedom of speech in relation to political ideas is new and that nobody has mentioned it. We already know that Murphy had. I also draw his attention to some comments I made on 17 April, particularly to elucidate an argument that might well have informed his mind. In that speech I drew his attention to a number of United States cases, which basically put a simple proposition. You do not need to go to the Human Rights Commission to be told this or to study law to understand it; you just need to understand the premises on which this place works.

How does it work? People get elected to do what other people want. Every now and then we have an election. People like those in the gallery can decide whether they want to re-elect those opposite—I do not think they will re-elect them next time—or whether they would like to elect us. They will also decide how many of these magpies of politics that are under the table, otherwise referred to as the Australian Democrats, or Independents they will elect. How will they do that? They will only do that if they have some idea of what we think and what we and the Government have done. Information in relation to these matters is passed on through advertising. I admit that not all of it is substantive, but advertising does not have to be substantive to pass on a message. All it has to do is promote debate on the political issues.

In my speech in April I drew the Minister's attention to the case of Monitor Patriot Co. v Roy, in which he would have found in relation to the freedom of speech argument in the United States these words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . has its fullest and most urgent application precisely to the conduct of campaigns for political office.
The judgment of another case, Mills v Alabama, states:
There is practically universal agreement that a major purpose of the Amendment—
that is, the free speech amendment—
was to protect the free discussion of governmental affairs . . . including discussions of candidates.

Another United States case, Buckley v Valeo, is worth mentioning. In that case, the point was made that the Government, in seeking to put a limitation on the restriction of advertising, was necessarily reducing the quantity of expression by restricting the number of issues discussed, the depth of their exploration and the size of the audience it reached. The court went on to point out that it would be disastrous to exclude all citizens and groups, except candidates and political parties and the institutional press, from the use of the most effective modes of communication. Television and radio have become the most indispensable instruments of effective political free speech.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the argument of cost that has been raised by both the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party. They want to say that people with money are bad bogymen. I do not attribute bad faith to people with money in the first instance. This point is constantly repeated in a number of United States cases: one cannot make the assumption that just because one person has $2,000 that person ought not be able to put his or her view. One cannot make that assumption, because if 2,000 people want to put a view and they all put in a dollar they will have the $2,000 to put their view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Senator Schacht may scoff at that reasoning, but it is the very reasoning that allows the system to carry on as it does now. Senator Kernot raised a problem with limiting freedom of speech in 28 days out of 365 days. The penny should have dropped in Senator Kernot's mind that the community does not really want to hear from us all day every day. But if the day comes around when people take the casting of a vote as a responsibility there will be a greater interest in who is doing what. It is precisely at that time that freedom of speech, especially in relation to political issues, should be protected.

PARA.TAB: So there is no point in saying, `I am going to cut off your arm when you desperately need it, but you can have it for the rest of the year'; that is absolutely ludicrous. It is precisely during election campaigns that we must have this freedom of speech. That is why I do not support the arguments put forward by the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this matter of public importance that has been raised by the Liberal Party and deal with a couple of matters arising out of the decision of the High Court. I, like a number of people, have had a chance to read the decision that has been given. All of us will take some time to study in depth the reasons behind the judgment of the High Court. Firstly, it was not a unanimous decision. Even amongst the four who voted one way, different opinions are given about the reasoning.

PARA.TAB: I believe that determining the real meaning of this decision will be a feast for the constitutional lawyers, who are trying to get grants for the next 20 years. The basic decision of the High Court is that, in our Constitution, there is an implied right to freedom of communication. Justice Mason uses the term `freedom of communication' on page 18 of the decision—he does not use `freedom of speech'—as though he is more interested in the delivery modes of speech rather than free speech itself. That is a significant difference. I believe that he is trying to get around his very difficult position in this decision of implying that under the Constitution the Government's legislation was not valid. Nowhere in his decision does Justice Mason quote a particular clause of the Constitution to guarantee the implication of freedom of communication.

The judgment quotes various decisions of similar cases in Canada, the United States and Great Britain. It quotes all the other similar democracies comparable to ours but completely ignores the fact that all those other comparable countries already have limits, or outright bans, on political advertising. Justice Mason blithely ignores that precedent in those countries and talks about freedom of communication. On page 18, he says:

SPEECH.PARA: Only by exercising that freedom—
that is the freedom of communication—
can the citizen communicate his or her views on the wide range of matters that may call for, or are relevant to, political action or decision.
On page 19, he quotes Professor Harrison Moore:
. . . "[t]he great underlying principle" of the Constitution was that the rights of individuals were sufficiently secured by ensuring each an equal share in political power.

Nowhere does he come to terms with the fact that the ability to exercise political power in our community can be very much influenced by access to financial resources. Justice Mason made a very substantial mistake in not understanding that an equal share means that one does not allow money to determine how much of that equal share one has. Again, it shows a lack of understanding of the political process in a modern society.

PARA.TAB: On page 21 of his decision, Justice Mason says that we are not talking about a bill of rights. He does not want to get into an argument that there is a bill of rights which has an expanded view about freedom of speech. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether freedom of communication in relation to public affairs and political discussion is substantially different from an unlimited freedom of communication. . .

He is trying to get off the hook of implying that there is freedom of speech in the Constitution while wanting to imply that there is freedom of communication. It is legal sophistry at its worst and it does not do our High Court any good to use it to try to get itself off its own hook. On page 23 of the judgment Justice Mason says:
Generally speaking, it will be extremely difficult to justify restrictions imposed on free communication which operate by reference to the character of the ideas or information.

That means that if some people in the community who want to form themselves into a political party can get around every other limitation we have elsewhere in the laws, such as limits on obscenity, and various other judgments that have been made by law which have been upheld—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was speaking about the judgment of the High Court and, in particular, comments made by Chief Justice Mason in the decision of the High Court to oppose the Government's legislation and to declare it unconstitutional in that there is an implied freedom of communication in the Constitution. Page 23 of his decision says:

SPEECH.PARA: Generally speaking, it will be extremely difficult to justify restrictions imposed on free communication which operate by reference to the character of the ideas or information.

In that particular section he raises in my mind the spectre that this will override much of the legislation of the governments of Australia—Federal and State—over the last 100 years or more on such things as obscenity and defamation. For example, I do not think it stretches the imagination too much to say that if this position proceeds the X-rated movie industry based here in Canberra could form a political party and then use that as a basis to say that it could distribute its material under the guise of freedom of communication, if not freedom of speech.

PARA.TAB: Those are the sorts of implications that come about when we have a High Court ruling that says there is an implied, not a direct, power in the Constitution. I do not believe Australian parliaments and the Australian people ought to automatically accept the High Court's right to imply anything into the Constitution. It is the people themselves, either directly through referendum or in the parliaments of Australia, who should have the final say. On page 24 of the same decision Chief Justice Mason says:

SPEECH.PARA: But, in the ultimate analysis, it is for the Court to determine whether the constitutional guarantee has been infringed in a given case. And the Court must scrutinize with scrupulous care restrictions affecting free communication in the conduct of elections for political office for it is in that area that the guarantee fulfils its primary purpose.

I reject that notion. I think the Australian people should reject the notion that an unelected appointed body, the High Court of Australia, can determine what the laws of Australia are by saying it is implied in the Constitution. My notion of democracy and the notion of democracy of this Australian community is that it elects people to Parliament to make the laws and if it does not like what they make it votes them out at the next election. It is a very simple definition of democracy, but I think it is the best going.

PARA.TAB: I do not like the idea that unelected non-responsible organisations, even as august as the High Court, can say that the legislature can have its laws overturned because in its judgment there is something implied. I would accept it to be different if it said that a particular clause of the Constitution, which is clear-cut, has been broken and it rules that way but I do not accept that an implied power can overrule the legislation of the Parliament.

I note that last week the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peter Costello, noted the significance of the High Court's decision and raised the issue that judges of the High Court will have to come under review and discussion about their political role. He accepts the fact that the judges will be making political decisions which are open to wide interpretation. That is a road that the High Court of Australia has previously not gone down, although I believe sometimes in the past, even interpreting particular sections of the Constitution, High Court judges have not been able to divorce their political preferences or prejudices from the decisions they make.

I believe that in this issue we will have to have a wide community debate to work out what are the responsibilities of the legislature and what are the responsibilities of the High Court. Chief Justice Mason believes that the High Court has the power to overturn legislation. Apparently only yesterday Justice Toohey argued in a speech in Darwin—I am quoting from the press so I do not know whether this is a direct quote—that the High Court had the power and the right to frustrate the will of Parliament by striking down legislation in order to protect and promote individual liberty. That is a statement by one of the justices of the High Court which indicates that as far as he is concerned they have a much wider role than they have had in the past.

I say to conservative members opposite that at the moment they are lauding this decision of the High Court by seeing it in terms of a political victory. But I suspect that this issue will come back and bite them at some stage in the future and they will be screaming and jumping up and down that the High Court, under the guise and interpretation that Justice Toohey has taken, has a wider role to `frustrate' the will of Parliament. I do not believe any unelected body has the right to frustrate the will of Parliament.

If justices of the High Court—whether it is Justice Toohey or Chief Justice Mason—believe that there is an implied right to guarantee the freedom of communication and overturn legislation, it is no longer a legal view, it is a political view. If they have that political view they should step down from the High Court and stand for Parliament and take the political debate on. They should not use the High Court bench to make political statements.

In the early 1940s Justice Evatt stepped down from the High Court where he had served for at least 10 years to stand for Parliament. He was elected and then served in the Australian Parliament for nearly 20 years. He understood the difference between a judicial interpretation and political activity. He did the honourable thing of putting himself in front of the people to be elected to this Parliament and to take part in the public debate. We are going to have a position where members of the public and members of the Parliament will criticise judges of the High Court and judges will probably say that this is an attack on the independence of the judiciary. When they start making political decisions, such as they did last week when they overrode the Government's legislation, they are relying on an implied power which is open to the widest interpretation. I do not believe that in any form of sensible democracy we should allow a group of people, unelected, appointed to the age of 70, to have the power to make that decision.

Finally, if the High Court is only carrying out a judicial role of interpretation of specific sections of the Constitution we can certainly accept that people with eminent legal qualifications should be appointed to the High Court. Once it starts making political decisions, the Parliament of Australia and the people will start demanding that the members of the High Court reflect a wider view in the community than those who just happen to have served the whole of their lives in the legal profession.

I do not think anyone could say that the present seven High Court justices represent the balance of the Australian community. Six of the seven are white Anglo-Saxon males and the other is a female white Anglo-Saxon. They do not represent a broad cross-section of the Australian community by either experience or occupation. If they are going to make political judgments, the High Court ought to reflect the make-up and the mixture of the Australian community. Therefore, the demand will come very quickly that we should appoint people to the High Court who reflect the community and not reflect some high legal qualification alone because they are not reflecting the community at the moment.

This has been a momentous decision by the High Court. It is much wider than just the issue of the Government's Bill that was passed in this Parliament last year. There are fundamental issues at stake. The High Court has put its foot in the water and I only hope that the community over the coming months and years has an opportunity to define how the High Court should operate and that we do not allow seven unelected members of the High Court to second-judge every piece of legislation that the elected representatives of the Australian Parliament pass.

However, despite all the AMLC's best efforts to encourage Australians to eat more meat, we have a situation at present in Australia where drought and recession have affected our domestic production; slaughterings and consumption and a variety of other factors have impacted on our export levels; and domestically, sadly, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen said, Australians are eating less meat. Beef, veal and lamb have all lost market share and butchers are buying and selling less meat, which is rather sad. As I said, I have a pecuniary interest in producing good beef for people to eat.

The domestic trade is worth some $2.6 billion, made up of fresh beef, veal, lamb, pork and poultry. Beef and veal and lamb both lost one per cent in market share to 53 per cent and 16 per cent respectively. The retail price of beef rose only 0.4 per cent and lamb actually fell by 4 per cent. This was despite the fact that Australian meat is among the cheapest and certainly the best quality meat in the world. This is all despite active effective advertising, slick promotion and increased awareness campaigns to encourage the housewife to buy more meat.

The range of products now available for the health conscious shopper are outstanding. Lean beef and trim lamb are designed to appeal to the diet- and health-conscious family, and I believe butchers have faced the challenge of promoting their product in an admirable manner. Why then are Australians eating less meat? I am sure that I do not know the answer, and I hope the AMLC is working on a solution to that problem. That is very important to me and very important to Australia's meat industry, especially the beef industry.

What I do know is that, nationally, we are slaughtering at high levels, particularly our females. Some 44 per cent of all slaughterings of our national herd are females. The herd is being run down. SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this report is to provide the details for the start of the process of rolling capital funds into university operating grants from 1994. However, the problem remains that the Government still does not go far enough in deregulating the higher education system. The plan outlined by the Government in this report means that the universities will still be hindered by the development of profiles and management reports which are an unnecessary drain on the resources of our universities. The Federal Government needs to accept the fact that higher education will meet the demands placed upon it only it if it is given the freedom and the autonomy to act so that it does not have to worry about government criteria.

PARA.TAB: The policy outlined in this report also fails to address the problem of universities that are trying to catch up on inadequate capital funding over the past 10 years. The main concern relating to the catch-up and development is outlined in the summary of responses to the discussion paper sent out to the higher education institutions by the Minister. This also reveals concerns by the universities that the options outlined in the discussion paper do not allow for increased capital costs of emerging institutions such as the central coast campus of the University of Newcastle in my region. Concerns are also expressed about the timing of the roll-in, arguing that some institutions still have to catch up the phase of development that has occurred over the last 10 years.

A case in point is the University of Southern Queensland. This institution is an excellent example of the way in which higher education is heading in this country with its focus on open learning. It is apparent that it has received a raw deal in capital funding recently. It has been described as outrageous that USQ has not received its capital funding grant to enable it to build a technologies building despite previous assurances to the contrary by the Minister.

The university missed out on capital funding in the 1980s through no fault of its own and, because of the incompetence of the Minister, it is about to miss out again. The people of southern Queensland should be outraged. This university is the only one in Australia to offer a degree in agricultural engineering and rural industry. It has already committed $1.1m to the end of 1993 for research. With sufficient capital funding, this research could be five times as much as that stated by the Deputy Vice-Chancellor of the USQ. The approach to capital funding is inconsistent with the value added industry and with allowing the young people of southern Queensland to reach their potential.

The report that the Senate is now considering outlines a discretionary pool of funding that allows for capital development assistance to those institutions that are at a significant development stage, such as new campuses or those that are continuing to grow at extraordinarily high rates. Our higher education institutions have been demanding more autonomy and freedom when trying to raise revenue to finance these activities, so they can welcome this small but significant improvement. I remember when this Government came into power that it accused us of being soft on corporate crime. It promised the Australian people that it would set up machinery to ensure that corporate crooks were properly brought to justice. What has happened is that the machinery the Government set up has totally broken down. There seems to have been a total absence of direction by the Attorney-General, the Minister responsible in this area, to ensure that the criminal law is properly applied in these instances of major corporate crime.

It seems that Mr Hartnell, the chairman of the ASC, took it upon himself to allocate the resources basically towards regulatory functions of the ASC rather than criminal prosecutions. This came after we had been told that the 16 major corporate breaches or alleged breaches in particular, which were referred to as the big 16 cases, would be thoroughly investigated and that those who breached the law would be brought to justice.
