What was the Minister doing whilst this philosophical breach was taking place between these two senior heads of these departments that could result in this breakdown? It seems that the Attorney-General was sitting on his hands. Basically, he did nothing until this matter came into the public forum. Sadly, it came into the public forum through leaks to newspapers and when these senior bureaucrats had laid their complaints before a parliamentary committee. That is not good enough.

The Minister should have been taking action, not only to solve the philosophical difference between these senior bureaucrats but also to ensure that this conflict of view as to how these matters should be progressed should not be allowed to defeat the administration of justice in the way that it was. So the Minister not only did not get in and sort out the philosophical difference but he also did not take action to ensure that the administration of justice did not suffer as a result of this breach. It seems that this trouble has been brewing for some 12 months or so. It is simply not good enough.

What are the consequences of this breach? As I said a moment ago, we have been given these undertakings that, in relation to the big 16, adequate work was being done. But Mr Rozenes, the DPP, alleges that only one or two investigators are working on some of the big 16 cases. That will be ineffective, given the complexity of the matters. Mr Robinson, of the ASC, told Senate Estimates Committee E that in a significant number of these big 16 cases there had been referrals of breach to the DPP.

Who is telling the truth? Why is not the Minister getting to the bottom of this? Estimates Committee E was told that there had not yet been any convictions in any of the big 16 matters except in relation to the Bond matter. That is totally unsatisfactory and it is too late for the Minister to come before the Parliament and complain about it. I believe that a Senate committee ought to look at this total breakdown of the administration of justice, find exactly where the fault lies and do something positive about it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to briefly address papers Nos 9 and 10 before the Senate tonight. One of them is a paper by the Attorney-General setting out the general principles that should underlie the prosecution of corporate wrongdoing. The other one is a paper called Serious Corporate Wrongdoing: Direction Relating to Investigation and Enforcement. This paper sets out regulations and procedures which are to be followed from now on to ensure that the Australian Securities Commission and the Director of Public Prosecutions work effectively and harmoniously in the prosecution of corporate wrongdoers.

PARA.TAB: One can only say that one wished either these directions were not necessary or that they were issued much sooner. Very clearly, there was a conflict between those two law enforcement agencies which, I suspect, led to some of our corporate cowboys getting off scot-free and others perhaps being given a chance to get away with civil proceedings whereas they should have been criminally prosecuted. As one of the witnesses who gave evidence before the Joint Standing Committee on Corporations and Securities, which held a hearing on these matters, said, the only real deterrent for these corporate wrongdoers is not a fine but a stay in gaol.

On this basis, I welcome, no matter how belatedly it is, the issue of the directions by the Attorney-General. But I foreshadow that, after a number of months—may be six or 12 months—have elapsed under these directions, I will move that another inquiry be held by the Joint Standing Committee on Corporations and Securities to ensure that these directions are operating effectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with a paper by the Attorney-General relating to the giving of directions to the Australian Securities Commission and the Director of Public Prosecutions. Let me say that this imbroglio manifests what is wrong with this Government. It has no direction, no leadership and no capacity to govern.

PARA.TAB: We have a situation where there is an internecine conflict going on between the DPP and the ASC. It developed into a subterranean battle and it was only ultimately resolved by a very embarrassed and wrong-footed Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) when it became public. It became public because of the frustration of the two bodies leaking correspondence to the media to try to win a political point. It is absolutely appalling when law enforcement agencies of this nature and with these grave responsibilities fight their battles for supremacy, control and direction through the media. We wonder why white-collar Australia has treated them with scant regard in the past.

As I say, it is symptomatic of this Government that the Attorney-General was clearly the last to know. For the better part of this conflict he did a Pontius Pilate and washed his hands and said, `My goodness, my goodness, please solve this dilemma for me'. Of course, the war simply went on and the temperature went up. As I say, ultimately, out of embarrassment and discomfort, the Attorney-General brought them together and the battle continued in his office. He sent them away and put together some fairly elementary directions that they ought to take in the future. He gave directions for the ASC to persist with its investigations in terms of corporate and criminal law—

TALK.START.PARA: —They should confer with each other and things like that. It is a necessary requirement for senior bureaucrats.

—As I said, when the DPP and the ASC have to be got together by the Attorney-General and he has to hold their hands and tell them, `Shake hands, make up and sort it out, and just to make sure you do I am going to have a couple in my Department keep an eye on you to make sure that you keep your promises'—a real kiss and make up—it is no wonder that law enforcement under this Government is treated with such scant regard.

PARA.TAB: Ultimately, because I am not privy to the machinations that were taking place, I am not certain of where the fault lies with these two except that there was a total lack of direction. Instead of the Attorney-General getting on to this at the beginning, calling them in and straightening the matter out, given his responsibilities and his obligations, the thing went on and on. To the extent that it did, I am not certain ultimately of where in these two agencies the fault lay—if it can be apportioned.

But it does show that this Government seems incapable of giving proper and firm direction as to what it intends and what it wishes with respect to law enforcement in this country. Let us now hope that there is a civilised, proper and responsible approach taken to this matter and that we do not in the future see scalps on the wall of a corporate nature with criminal prosecutions afoot simply so that this Government can be seen to be doing something as distinct from doing something.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pendulum will swing.

—That is right. The tragedy of law enforcement at a Federal level in this country is that it is being driven by political expediency. Whether it is the National Crime Authority, the extension of the Costigan inquiry, increased powers for the ASC or the DPP, it is always reactionary, always driven by excesses committed in the community, because this Government does not have the capacity to make measured judgment about how these matters should be dealt with.

PARA.TAB: Let us hope that these criminal and civil proceedings are approached in a proper, objective and fair way and that this Government does not lurch into a new bout of persecutions, as distinct from prosecutions, simply so that it can say at the end of the day that it has been successful. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a corrigendum to the Auditor-General's Report No. 1 of 1992-93—Report on Ministerial Portfolios—Budget sittings 1992.
—I present a letter from the US Ambassador responding to the resolution of the Senate concerning agricultural subsidies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter that has just been tabled is dated 25 September. In the body of the letter, there is mention that the Ambassador who has signed the letter convened a meeting of the Australia-American Parliamentary Friendship Group on 16 September for the purpose of discussing with the leader of the delegation from Washington concerning agricultural matters Australia's objections to the way that the United States has extended the EEP scheme.

PARA.TAB: This letter reiterated the point that all those present at that meeting on 16 September made quite clear that they did not accept the reason given by the United States for the extension of the EEP scheme. I think it is important to read some of the text of the letter in order to put it into context. The letter was written in response to a motion passed by the Senate regarding agricultural subsidies. The letter advises that the text of that resolution has been transmitted to Washington. His Excellency then said:
I would like to take this opportunity to point out that the United States and Australia have entered into frequent bilateral agricultural technical consultations.

SPEECH.PARA: He then mentioned the meeting of the Parliamentary Friendship Group and said:

At that meeting, the leader of the U.S. Delegation . . . responded to questions from interested Parliamentarians for over one and a half hours. These questions were quite pointed regarding the use of export subsidies by the United States and the closeness of the relationship between the United States and Australia.

PARA.TAB: We note that the Senate Resolution also calls upon the European Community to exercise moderation in the use of its export subsidies. As you are aware, the U.S. Export Enhancement Program is designed to force that outcome in the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round.

SPEECH.PARA: It was precisely that point—that is, the reason given for the extension of the EEP program—that the meeting on 16 September made quite clear that members of the Australia-America Parliamentary Friendship Group did not accept.

PARA.TAB: When we realise that this is an election year and that the Mid-West of the United States is an important voting section, we know from President Bush's speeches in those States that it is an election ploy. When we see Governor Clinton, who has pulled ahead in the polls, go into those same States and say, `The current administration has not done enough for you, we'll do more', we realise that we are getting into a Dutch auction.

The problem with the way this program is operating is that the subsidy is being paid, but we in Australia are being asked to bear part of the burden of that subsidy. The reason I say that is that because of the subsidy that the United States makes available, the price of wheat worldwide is lowered. There is no doubt that we will sell our wheat, but the price at which it will be sold will be lower than it would have been had there been no subsidy from the United States. Later in this debate colleagues of mine will deal very specifically with that question of price.

Recently I read an article in the press carrying comments by Mr Baker, who is now running President Bush's campaign, saying that Australians should stop whingeing about the export enhancement program and that it will do us no good if we just keep whingeing. The points that we make are based on more than just a simple whinge.

The basis of the criticisms that we made at that meeting on 16 September, and continue to make, is that we do not accept that the EEP program is somehow designed wholly and solely to make the European Community come to the table to have a satisfactory round of the GATT. As these subsidies are paid, more and more American farmers become dependent upon them. That in turn affects the price of land, which in turn affects the size of mortgages, which in turn affects the banks which hold those mortgages. Every time an additional subsidy is paid the merry-go-round goes on and it becomes ever more difficult to wean those farmers off that scheme.

The very simple lesson is that if that subsidy were pulled away, there would be a detrimental effect on the price of land, on the servicing of those mortgages and on the viability of those banks. That is a real problem which has existed in the United States ever since the EEP program has been introduced or prior to that when people were being paid not to grow. The problem for us is that it affects the price we receive for our wheat. There can be all sorts of discussions about the fact that we produce better wheat than the Americans, and that they produce more wheat than we produce. The Americans say that they will take every opportunity to protect the interests of non-subsidising exporters such as Australia. I am again quoting the letter.

Clearly, unless we have applying to our wheat a document equivalent to the Andriessen letter—a letter which applies with regard to the European Community and our beef—we could perhaps understand that there was some meaning in the undertaking given by President Bush to the farmers who demonstrated outside Parliament House when he was here last year and in subsequent statements. But in the meantime, if I can take up the point that Mr Baker made, it is not simply a matter of Australia whingeing. What the United States is doing with that program is making the subsidy an inbuilt part of the economy. The political will becomes harder each time that subsidy is made greater.

In an election year in the United States, with President Bush making his commitment to farmers and then Governor Clinton starting to get into a Dutch auction by saying, `Anything he can do, we can do better and more', we see that the whole problem becomes greater.

So far as forcing the European Community to the table to find some satisfactory solution to the Uruguay Round of the GATT is concerned, it would be a fallacy if the United States convinced itself that somehow its action with subsidies had caused that to happen. One of the things that will force the European Community to come to any sort of accommodation with regard to the common agricultural policy is simply the financial difficulty that its member nations will get into with regard to the cost of expanding the CAP to cover lands within eastern Germany or other fallow lands which are presently not cultivated.

It is important that countries such as Australia and other countries in the Cairns Group continue to voice their opposition to, disapproval and strong non-acceptance of the fiction that has become the official reason for the expansion of the EEP scheme. I thought that at the meeting on 16 September there was an acceptance by the people in the United States delegation that we simply did not accept that reason as valid. I thought we finally got that message through.

Until there is an understanding between people who have been friends of long standing and who wish to accept the word of a trading partner and a strong ally that there will be an honouring of commitments given, we will continue to see a souring of the relationship. In our part of the world a continued relationship between Australia and the United States, the continuing relationship between the United States and Japan and the importance of APEC are all factors which contribute to the growth of our region and to our region truly living up to its name: Pacific.

The problem is that when agricultural trade is distorted, all trade is distorted. We simply cannot set agricultural trade aside and say that it is somehow different. It is not. The effect of trade policy can also be geopolitical. Indeed, this question is geopolitical.

We understand that this is an election year and that promises are being made. But I think it would be most reasonable on our part to ask that when the election is over, the additional subsidies and those that have gone before are dismantled so that we can see both our nations pursuing policies of free trade which enable those countries which are efficient to have the competitive edge to which they are entitled.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the letter that the President of the Senate received from Mr Mel Sembler, the Ambassador for the United States. I regret to say that I find the letter quite contemptuous in its offhanded brevity. It does not really address the issue of what damage is being done to Australian wheat farmers; nor does it hold out any hope at all that the United States is prepared to consider what it is doing and to change its ways. As has been previously stated by Senator Bishop, in a very lengthy and erudite exposition, it is quite clear that our farmers are going to suffer. And we can put it quite bluntly: they are being bankrupted. They are not being bankrupted because the United States has any hope of forcing the European Community to the negotiating table in the Uruguay Round but rather because President Bush is concerned about his re-election prospects in the United States. Anyone reading the newspapers in Australia or overseas would have to come to the same conclusion.

PARA.TAB: This shedding of crocodile tears by the Opposition when it rejected a stronger action that was proposed in the Senate is really quite laughable. The notices of motion proposed by Senator Panizza and Senator Brownhill, amongst others, contained words such as `deplore', `condemn' and `abhor' in relation to the actions of the United States.

I proposed a notice of motion suggesting that we should tell the United States that it was no longer welcome to share our defence facilities and that as long as it was not treating us as friends we were not prepared to treat the United States as a friend by allowing it to use its bases on Australian soil. In strategic terms they are of no use to Australia's security anyway. So why not make a statement to the United States that has some chance of real effect? I was delighted to see that Mr Malcolm Fraser, a former Liberal Prime Minister, had more courage than members of the Opposition in today's Parliament. He wrote in the Sunday Age a week ago that the United States should have been told to quit the bases if it were not prepared to treat Australia as a friend and ally. Quite clearly, we cannot treat as a friend and ally a country that pays absolutely no heed to the damage it is doing to our wheat farmers.

This behaviour will continue unless the Australian Government is prepared to tell the United States that we are not going to stand for that sort of behaviour. The Australian Government is unlikely to have the courage to do that unless it is supported by the Opposition. So I believe that it is time that we stopped making noises like a doormat, because if we do we will continue to be treated and trodden on like a doormat. We should state quite clearly and categorically that we have an interest in protecting our wheat farmers and that our Government should take action accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —(9.54 p.m.)—I rise to support the motion to take note of the American Ambassador's response to the Senate's resolution of September. I think it should be put on record here that, whatever our discomfort, concern and disgust at the American export enhancement program to subsidise wheat sales into our traditional markets, one has to concede that the European Community is the No. 1 enemy of free trade that affects our agricultural production in Australia.

PARA.TAB: To use the term used by Mr Fischer, the Leader of the National Party, the Americans certainly should not be trade enemy No. 1 but should, I suspect, be trade enemy No. 2 in the list of priorities. One should remember that at least the Americans announce when they are going to dump subsidised wheat on our markets. The European Community makes no such announcement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it make it better?

—No, it does not make it better, but at least the Americans announce when they are going to do it. The European Community makes no such announcement; it just happens. One has to admit that the Europeans have been doing these things longer and at a much greater rate, with effects on free trade and agricultural marketing, than have the Americans.

PARA.TAB: It has to be accepted that the Americans have responded to the European Community. In no way do I wish to reduce my criticism of the American initiatives in this area. The situation has certainly been brought about this year by the electoral consequences. President Bush can see his chances of re-election slipping away and Mr Clinton can see his chances growing. As the previous speaker said, both candidates are engaged in a Dutch auction. They want to grab some of the last few vital votes in the electoral college from the agricultural states of Mid-West America.

I want to emphasise that our criticism from this Parliament and our No. 1 target is the European Community, and that our No. 2 target—not by a big margin—is the United States. We do not oppose America or the European Community giving income support to farmers, but we make a real distinction between that and production subsidies. If there are quite legitimate reasons in both countries, for social or economic reasons, to encourage people to stay on their land by giving them income supplements, then that is quite different from encouraging them to over-produce and sell those subsidised goods in our markets and thus affect world agricultural trade.

I was not able to attend the recent meeting of the Australia-America Parliamentary Friendship Group, but when delegations from both the European Community and the United States have come before the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the Committee has put to representatives of both countries that we support their right to seek income support for their people. But we find it absurd that the Americans spend tens of thousands of dollars, or even hundreds of thousands of dollars, giving income support to individual farmers. In the case of the European Community, they spend tens of thousands of pounds in a similar way in Great Britain.

The other night on television a British farmer was interviewed saying he was being paid #25,000 per annum to take about 40 acres of his 200 acres of land out of production. Even he thought it was a rort and an extraordinary waste of taxpayers' money. He favoured the free market system. But as Great Britain was part of the European Common Market he was paid to take that land out of production. In the end the taxpayers of the European Community will have to pay that extraordinary cost.

I agree with previous speakers that it is not exactly a fulsome letter of defence of the American export enhancement program. I think the Senate was deserving of a more detailed letter in response to a resolution carried unanimously by the Senate.

What has been interesting in Australia in the past month has been the various political responses to what the European Community and the Americans have been announcing. If 10 years ago someone had said that a former conservative Prime Minister of this country would suggest that as a penalty for the American trade decisions the position of the American-Australian joint facilities in Australia should be reviewed, most people would have thought that there was something wrong with the water one had been drinking. I never thought I would see the day when a former conservative Prime Minister would publicly state that, in view of the American position on trade, it is time the question of joint facilities be put on the table.

It seems that a very odd coalition is emerging in Australia on this issue. On one side we have what one would call the extreme left of the political spectrum—an assortment of former members of the Communist Party, Trotskyites, general anarchists and so on, and people who are indirectly associated through the nuclear disarmament parties. These people, who are demanding the withdrawal of the joint facilities from Australia, are being joined by members of the various farming organisations who are now raising this issue. Members of the National Party are raising it. Of course, a former conservative Prime Minister, who in the 1950s and 1960s was noted for his extreme anti-communist views, his very strong defence of the so-called American alliance, is now openly suggesting that unless America changes its trade policies as they affect Australia, the position of the joint facilities should be reviewed in Australia.

It is an amazing coalition. The conservative Right and the extreme Left in Australia have a similar view about the action that should be taken against the United States. I do not believe that so far that view is the majority view in the Australian community. However, I recognise that if this debate continues it is inevitable that more and more of the Australian community in the mainstream of the two major political parties—my own Party and the Liberal Party—will also take views similar to what the former conservative Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, said recently.

Also part of the debate in the post-Cold War period is the role that the joint facilities should fulfil in respect of international affairs and strategic matters. I believe it is inevitable that there will be debate about their future in Australia. There should be a sound debate about their role in the international community of being able to assist in the international verification of weapons treaties and of monitoring developments around the world. For example, we all know that the joint facilities in Australia played a critical role in monitoring Scud missile attacks from Iraq on Israel. I think that is an absolutely defensible role for the joint facilities.

So I do not think we should automatically jump up and down on the trade issue and say that the joint facilities should go because we are getting hit over the head by the Americans on trade. There are wider international security issues at stake in the post-Cold War period that enhance the reasons the joint facilities should maintain in Australia.

I believe that the Australian community will start reviewing the role of the joint facilities because they are no longer needed in purely Cold War terms. We all know that one of the two super powers—the Soviet Union—no longer exists. The President of Russia, Boris Yeltsin, was freely elected two years ago by the Russian people. I understand that he received more votes in that election than George Bush received in 1988. He is a freely and democratically elected President. So the Cold War which justified the joint facilities no longer exists.

I do warn and caution those opposite, particularly people like Malcolm Fraser, that before we put our card on the table and say, `Unless you give us a break on trade it is out with the joint facilities', we ought to take a wider look at the role of the joint facilities. There are no longer three joint facilities. There are now two because North West Cape is an Australian facility. Nurrungar and Pine Gap have a role to play in international strategic matters, in monitoring and securing the so-called new world order international security arrangements. They have a role to play even in our own region.

I understand the frustration of some people. I am a bit bemused by Malcolm Fraser's frustration. When he was Defence Minister and when he was Prime Minister he did nothing other than defend in absolute terms the secrecy of the joint facilities. Now he says that they should be put on the table. I also say to those opposite, `If that is the only card you have to play, once you play it and nothing happens—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a graduated response.

—People like Malcolm Fraser are saying that this ought to be the card we play to get a better trade deal. If we play that card the Americans might say, `All right, we are pulling out of the joint facilities. We are winding them up and removing them from Australia but we are not making any changes to our trade policies'. We will not have much left to play with thereafter if that is the only card we have to play.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe that the blunt instrument approach that Malcolm Fraser on the right and some of the far Left—and not necessarily just the Democrats—are arguing is the best way to go about it. I think multilateral discussions are the best. I again emphasise that I believe the debate in Australia anyway should deal with the future of the joint facilities in the context of the new world order rather than just in the context of a trade debate.

Finally, I wish to comment on the Australian Government's response to the trade issue over the last month. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has quite rightly made it very clear that Australia's trade future in the total picture is within our own region of north Asia, east Asia and south-east Asia. Already 60 to 70 per cent—an ever increasing percentage—of our exports go to these regions. That should be the main game in town as far as our total trade picture is concerned. I think the very significant remarks made the week before last in Japan by our Prime Minister are a turning point in the debate in Australia about where our future lies.

That does not mean to say that we should ignore any opportunity that emerges to improve our trade relations with other countries. It should be noted that we have a $6 billion trade surplus with Japan. I think we have almost a similar trade deficit with the United States of America. So, as far as trade relations with America are concerned, the US is doing very nicely out of us in the general trade picture irrespective of that country dumping wheat into our markets around the world.

The Prime Minister spoke about the future role of APEC. I concede that Senator Bishop also made a similar point about the importance of APEC. I think we should welcome the indication from the Japanese that they support the Australian Government's view that there should be a meeting of APEC leaders, not just Foreign Ministers, to discuss trade and economic issues. This development is of considerable significance to the future trade prospects of this country.

In conclusion, I believe it is important for the Senate to note and to comment on the letter from the American Ambassador. This is just one of many opportunities that senators have had formally and informally to express their views. We should continue to express them to the Americans. But we should also make sure that we never miss the opportunity to express them even, in many cases, more forcibly to European Community representatives who come to this country. I think the European Community is marginally ahead of the United States in terms of who is doing the most damage to us. I think that should be noted. I again emphasise that at least the Americans announce when they are going into our markets. The Europeans never announce it and they do not get quite the same publicity that their intervention—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Spindler interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true. They never announce when they are corrupting one of our markets. It just happens and we find out about it months later.
—They both do it, but I will say this for the Americans: at least they front up and tell us when they are doing it; the Europeans do not.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If you want to use the Richter scale, it is 8.1 compared to 7.9. But it is a difference that I think ought to be noted. As I said before, the European Community started this process 25 years ago, with the common agricultural policy, and we have complained about it ever since. The EC has done the most rorting of trade and agricultural products. That is the No 1 priority. Not far behind—in the racing parlance, maybe only half a length behind—in the finish of the Melbourne Cup comes the Americans. Either way, all of us on both sides of the Parliament, whatever our emphasis, have the opportunity to act in a bipartisan, tripartisan or quadripartisan way in expressing to both the EC and the Americans our absolute hostility to the rorting of the trade in agricultural products.

—I, too, would like to refer to the letter from the United States Ambassador to the President following on from a notice of motion I gave some time ago, which motion was carried formally. We had a meeting with Mr Censky and the trade delegation that was out here. We were pretty lucky that we had that meeting; otherwise they would not have filled a quarter of a page, let alone the three-quarters of a page that they filled. All they referred to was that meeting. I attended that friendship meeting and I can tell honourable senators that it was anything but friendship. Mr Censky told us what they were doing: they were not attacking our market share; they were only going in where they thought the EC might have been going in. Even though Mr Censky said that he would leave our market share, he would not agree that what they were doing was depressing our prices.

PARA.TAB: Since Mr Bush made that announcement in North Dakota, South Dakota or wherever it was—incidentally, I was there a couple of years ago and took the chance to look at some of the farms, and some of the American wheat farms do not seem to be doing too badly to me, with their advanced equipment—the US started off with a subsidised sale of 220,000 tonnes of wheat to Pakistan, on the basis of a rumour that the EC was about to offer subsidy sales. Since to my knowledge the EC has not been in Pakistan with subsidised sales or any sort of sale, I would like to know where the rumour started. As far as I am concerned, it was probably started by a Pakistani wheat dealer. Pakistan is not a traditional EC market.

Senator Schacht mentioned in his contribution, in damming the EC—and I agree that the EC is as much to blame as the United States in this matter—that at least with the United States you know when it is going to do a subsidy deal, whereas you do not know with the EC. All I can say about that is: what is the difference? If you get stabbed from the front or the back you are dead, anyway. You will not even live long enough to know whether you were stabbed from the front or the back. So I do not see Senator Schacht's point.

Now the US has made a deal with India for one million tonnes of red wheat, valued at about $100m. Again, India is not a traditional EC market. The EC has not made a sale to India for five years. So, again, how can the US say that it is doing it because of the fear of subsidisation? They termed it a `pre-emptive strike'. Once again, is it on the basis of a rumour? Or is it just looking for market share? Mr Censky told us when he was here that he was not trying to get our market share; that he was only attacking the EC. But making a sale to India—a subsidised sale at that—has dampened the Australian potential to sell there. The Australian Wheat Board was hoping to make another sale in March. But from the reports I get from the Wheat Board and others at the moment, there is no way this can be done. As I said, earlier this year we made a sale of half a million tonnes of wheat to India. I cannot see how we can get to the next one.

I turn to the point Senator Evans made today—that the subsidised sale to India was of red wheat. Red wheat is regarded as being of lower quality than the average quality of Australian wheat. Nonetheless, it is still wheat. Senator Evans admitted that the sale had a dampening effect on the price that Australia can get for its better quality wheat. It does not matter how much better quality wheat Australia wants to sell to India or anyone else; if there is someone around offering a subsidised sale, it brings our price down. When you get away from the top quality baking wheat, when you are selling red wheat or ASW—Australian Standard White—you are dealing with protein; that is all you are dealing with. So if you have a downward pressure on any protein product, you have it right across the board. That includes sorghum and corn. The US grows a lot of corn and Australia has an expanding corn industry. A big corn crop or a subsidised corn crop will also affect wheat. It will have a dampening effect because, after all, it is trading in protein. So I cannot see why because the US made that sale in red wheat to India it should be different from if it were white wheat or high protein wheat.

The cry of the US that it uses the EEP against the EC only is wearing a little thin in Australia now. Internal criticism is mounting in the United States because of the cuts in spending caused by these subsidies being paid out of Treasury to the wheat farmers rather than flowing to programs that badly need it. Hopefully, this matter will be settled when the election has finally come and gone.

There seems to be a rumour amongst the press this year that subsidised sales as a result of Mr Bush's EEP are not going to affect price. The effects of subsidisation will not be any different to what happened two years ago. Leading up to harvest two years ago, we were looking at an estimated pool return of about $160 per tonne. At about the psychological time when the Australian Wheat Board was setting its estimate of the final pool return on which it does its borrowings, there were massive subsidised sales by the United States—up to $45 a tonne. What happened? That estimated pool return went down to about $115 a tonne, and that is where it remained. The fact is that private contracts were made in New South Wales, and probably southern Queensland and a few other places, on the basis of $160 a tonne, which the estimated pool return was going to be. They are the only ones who did any good out of the wheat crop of that year. The pool went back to $115, and that is where it stayed, and it was a disaster.

This year we were looking at an estimated pool return on the date that Mr Bush made his announcement—at least a month ago now—at around $160 a tonne, climbing to about $185 a tonne. That is normal. With the flush of the northern wheat harvest, the card price gets depressed. Normally, it gets down to about $150. But as the northern hemisphere places its wheat, the card price gradually rises. We are expected to get $185 by the end of this month. That would have set the pool return for this year.

The immediate effect of the Wheat Board's next appraisal was a drop of only $5 a tonne—back to about $155. But with the dampening effect of further sales to the likes of India, what is going to happen now? That is where it will stay. It will not have a hope of creeping towards $180 or $185. So much for the journalists who have a rumour around now that it will not affect the price. It is. It will have a total effect of at least $A30-$A35 a tonne, and that is the cream of the Australian wheat crop to the farmer.

Let us go further. It is not only farmers who are affected around Australia but also machinery dealers, storekeepers and people who want to expand their farms. All those people will be affected if there is, say, $35 to $40 a tonne less coming through to the farmers.

I ask a few pertinent questions. There are people from whom we have not heard in this debate. I have heard what Mr Kerin, the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, has had to say about this matter in the last month. I have not heard from Mr Crean, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy—a Minister from the trade union movement—and I was quite prepared to see what he could do in primary industry development. We have heard very few constructive comments from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on the situation. These people have been conspicuous by their silence.

It is time that the United States treated us as an ally in the same way that we have been an ally to it for the last 50 or 60 years. Senator Schacht offered us a challenge and Senator Spindler said that we should look at the joint defences. I do not believe we have to do that. We have to keep those joint defences. If we throw on the table that the Americans ought to pull out of Australia, they might take the idea up and be happy to go. We can work around this, but I do not want people such as Mr Sembler, Mr Bush or Mr Censky coming to Australia and telling us that they are not affecting our industry. They are affecting it, and they are being hypocritical about it in their statements and platitudes. There are ways to do it; the Australian Government should be more pro-active in getting us to where we ought to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be quite brief. I wish to make a comment about the attitude of the United States to Australia's concern about the impact of EEP upon our primary producers. For the Americans to be able to say that it is of minor or no impact is an absolute load of rubbish, and there is no other way to describe it.

PARA.TAB: I was at the US-Australian friendship group meeting briefly where this matter was debated and discussed for over an hour and a half. TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I raise tonight is similar to one I have raised previously: the issue of freedom of religion and, in particular, of Buddhists to practise their religion in Vietnam. As I said before, I have raised incidents where monks have been imprisoned; I have raised the question of the return of Buddhist property to the Buddhists in Vietnam. I know that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has previously made representations in relation to events which have occurred, and I want to ask him to again make representations to the Government of Vietnam on this matter.

PARA.TAB: There are two recent incidents to which I wish briefly to refer. The first is the death of a 25-year-old monk, the Venerable Thich Thien An. He resided at Thien Minh pagoda, Thu Duc, Saigon. He was taken by the Government, imprisoned and tortured. He died in prison in late September of this year, and the Government then spread the word that he had committed suicide. Nobody who knew him believes that. They know that he was taken; they know that he was imprisoned—he was not brought to trial; and they know that he was tortured. He was a young man who was very committed to what he was doing—learning and practising Buddhism. He was very dedicated to the work that he was carrying out in that capacity. From what I know of the incident, there seems to be good reason to believe that he was in fact killed by the authorities in prison, as suggested.

Just last week two monks were charged on the quite extraordinary pretext of illegal driving and were imprisoned. It happened at 11.30 a.m. on 2 October 1992 at Mac Thi Buoi Street, First District of Saigon. Arrested were two officials of the United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation, the Very Venerable Thich Khong Tanh and the Venerable Thich Tri Luc. In this there is some significance in that the Venerable Thich Khong Tanh was imprisoned in the year 1976 by the then communist government of Vietnam. He had at that time written to the communist Prime Minister protesting against the order to call up young Buddhist monks for military service. It was seen by the church at that time as one of the steps designed to destroy the Buddhist clergy. For that, he was imprisoned for some considerable time.

Just last week, as I said, he and his companion were arrested for a driving offence. To be arrested and imprisoned in this fashion for a driving offence seems, at least to me, absolutely extraordinary. But later the same day at about 8 p.m., the police went to the Lien Tri pagoda in the Thu Duc district where the Venerable Khong Tanh resided. They searched and took a number of documents from the place—documents which had been prepared and signed to be sent out to the domestic Vietnamese congregations and to overseas congregations.

I think we are entitled to ask when there will be freedom to practise Buddhism in Vietnam. It seems a great pity that this sort of persecution is continuing. Religious freedom does not exist in Vietnam; torture and the killing of monks is continuing; and the property of the church has not been restored to its rightful owners. I think there is serious infringement of human rights going on, from what I hear. I hope that the Minister will again make representations, through the Australian Embassy in Vietnam to the authorities there, protesting about this and making it plain that this is behaviour that we do not appreciate or support. The Buddhists in Vietnam have been there for a very long time and are very much a part of the history of that country. It seems to me impossible for Vietnam to again take its place in the world and say that it is a free country while this sort of persecution continues.

PARA.TAB: The other point I wanted to raise tonight which is even more significant is the campaign and notice of opposition to the Government's industrial relations Bill. It is appropriate that I remind this chamber and the Australian public of the position of the Government at that time and the position it would love to be in today. That legislation was to introduce a labour court as part of the Hancock committee report and to remove sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. That was the Government's position at that time and if it thought it had half a chance, it would follow that course again.

One must emphasise here the enormous importance of sections 45D and 45E in terms of giving justice in the industrial arena in Australia. They are the provisions which allow people to protect themselves against secondary boycotts wherever those secondary boycotts may come from. They are a very important part of law in this country today. At that time the Bill was also about removing industrial disputation from the law courts of Australia and, as I have already said, putting them under a labour court. This meant that if people were subjected to industrial action they did not have full access to the normal laws of the land. In other words, it was creating selective law separate from the laws of the land for privileged people who thought that, by what is commonly known as the abuse of union power, they could run this country through industrial action. It was going to separate them from the Federal Court, the supreme courts of the various States, the High Court and from the judicial appeals tribunal.

It is also worth noting here that both 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act were amendments introduced by the Fraser Government. The judicial appeals tribunal was also established as a result of legislation brought into this place by the Fraser Government, the last Liberal Government of this nation.

In recent times we have seen, for example in the Contractors Bill, that a commercial contractor who has a legitimate legal contract can be forced to appear before the Industrial Relations Commission to have that commercial contract interfered with. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 20 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that 1993 has been designated by the United Nations as International Year of Indigenous People, with an official launch scheduled in New York on 10 December 1992;
(2) What activities have been planned to mark this year which focuses on human rights and social justice for all indigenous people;
(3) Has a departmental officer been nominated to work with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in planning and co-ordinating activities for International Year of Indigenous People.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes

(2) The General Assembly has appointed the Under Secretary-General for Human Rights as Co-ordinator for the activities of the International Year of the World's Indigenous People and the Centre for Human Rights in Geneva as the co-ordinating body.
The Australian Torres Strait and Islander Commission has seconded an officer to assist the Centre in organising the International Year.

A program of United Nations sponsored activities and projects for the Year is still being finalised on the basis of consultations with representatives of governments and indigenous peoples. To that end, the General Assembly has adopted a program of activities to be undertaken at the national and international levels.
States were invited to adopt the following measures to ensure the Year's success:

Designate a contact person for the Year in the appropriate ministry and establish national committees composed of representatives of government, indigenous peoples and non-governmental organisations to prepare a national program of activities.
Raise public awareness through information and education projects.
Promote indigenous initiatives in areas such as radio and television and model projects on education, health, employment, housing and the environment.
Present information, prepared in partnership with indigenous people, about the situation prevailing in the country and the activities initiated during the Year.
Encourage participation of indigenous people in the preparation and implementation of all activities undertaken in connection with the Year.
Encourage indigenous organisations and communities to prepare their own programs and activities.
At the international level, the General Assembly recommended that the United Nations system:

Increase its co-operation, co-ordination and technical assistance for the solution of problems faced by indigenous communities in areas such as human rights, the environment, development, education and health.
Fund concrete projects for indigenous communities, reflecting the wishes of indigenous people, that can have a direct benefit to them.
Increase publicity, especially to indigenous people, on the work of the United Nations in areas related to the objectives of the Year.
Increase awareness of the existence of relevant international legal instruments related to the objectives of the Year and promote their widespread ratification and implementation.

Establish networks of indigenous organisations and communities for the sharing of information and experience in fields such as health care, bilingual education and resource and environmental management.
Contract or second indigenous organisations or persons with relevant expertise in carrying out projects for the benefit of indigenous communities.
Promote an international trade fair of indigenous products.

Provide technical assistance to governments wishing to make provisions in their legislation for protecting and promoting the human rights of indigenous people, in particular on questions of land, environmental protection and strengthening cultural identity, and provide technical and financial assistance.

The Government attaches great importance to achieving the objectives of the International Year, and as part of a co-ordinated response the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is planning a wide range of activities. These include:

A continuing emphasis on Australia's already high profile contribution to United Nations deliberations relevant to indigenous peoples, in particular, the UN Working Group on Indigenous Populations, and the Draft Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. Australia will also be seeking to ensure that indigenous peoples' issues are on the agenda for the 1993 World Conference on Human Rights.
Strengthening bilateral dialogue on indigenous peoples' issues with other countries;

Facilitating overseas exhibitions of and tours by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander performers and speakers, and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander participation in international conferences and seminars;

The distribution of information about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples overseas, including all Australian posts, overseas centres for Australian and/or indigenous peoples' studies. This would include a special series of radio interviews for international distribution with and about ATSI peoples and current issues affecting them, as well as a radio program featuring indigenous artists;
Researching the incorporation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander, and indigenous peoples' interests in international trade policy and activities;
Increasing DFAT officer knowledge and understanding of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander, and indigenous peoples' matters in departmental training programs;
Facilitating visits from indigenous peoples from other countries in Australia during 1993.

(3) An officer from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has been nominated to liaise with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission over the planning and co-ordination of activities for the International Year.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 19 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Coopers and Lybrand cost benefit study which analysed the costs of the Sydney Airport third runway project and which was prepared as part of the Airport Co-ordinating Task Force submission, been publicly released.

(2) Has the Minister considered a recent report by Liverpool City Council which favourably compared the employment benefits of the Badgerys Creek airport project with employment prospects of the Sydney Airport third runway project.

(3) Why have the recently tabled Federal Airports Corporation Regulations (Statutory Rules No. 255 of 1992), been structured so that the Federal Airports Corporation is exempted from complying with State Government environmental protection legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) All submissions on Draft Environmental Impact Statements (EIS's) prepared in accordance with the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 are public documents unless an author specifically requests that a submission remains confidential. The Airport Co-ordinating Task Force did not ask that its submission on the Sydney Airport third runway Draft EIS remain confidential and therefore the Coopers and Lybrand cost benefit study, which formed part of the Task Force's submission, is a public document.

(2) I am aware of the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research (NIEIR) study which included an assessment of the employment benefits of alternative airport developments in the Sydney Region. From the NIEIR study and work associated with the EIS's for Badgerys Creek and the Third Runway it is clear that only a directed development of a major international airport at Badgerys Creek would generate substantial employment growth in that Region. Such a development would not be commercially viable at this time and most of the employment growth at Badgerys Creek would be at the expense of other regions of Sydney.

(3) The Federal Airports Corporation Regulations establish a licensing regime to ensure that contractors working at the Sydney Airport third runway construction site and dredging sites in Botany Bay comply with environmental standards. These standards are a direct outcome of the environmental assessment process. Because the EIS on the third runway was prepared in accordance with Federal environmental assessment legislation (Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974) and not State legislation, the Regulations are intended to remove any doubt about the extent to which NSW laws apply to the construction of the runway.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 24 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Residents' Agreements, does the legislation governing the introduction of Residents' Agreements provide for two legitimate responses which both residents and nursing home proprietors can make: (a) sign the agreement in its present form; or (b) follow the notice provisions provided for in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Section 40AA(6)(bc) of the National Health Act 1953 provides that there must either be an "Agreement" in force between a resident and the proprietor of a nursing home OR if there is not an Agreement in force, the proprietor must comply with any "requirement" by the Minister which is consistent with the Charter of Residents' Rights and Responsibilities.

Both residents and proprietors, under the terms of this section of the Act can, therefore, choose whether or not to sign an Agreement. However, if an Agreement is not signed and not in force, the Act permits the Minister to issue a Notice of Requirements on the proprietor. The Act does not, however, empower the Minister to impose any commensurate responsibilities on a resident, whose rights are, nevertheless, protected by the Notice.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Academy of Science: Australian Academy of Humanities

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 24 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the details of the Equal Employment Opportunity policies of the Australian Academy of Science and the Australian Academy of Humanities.
(2) What are the procedures for admission to these academies.
(3) How are the academies funded.
(4) Will the Minister ensure both institutions comply with national legislation aimed at equity and social justice.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) According to the Academy By-Laws, `Fellows shall at the time of their election be normally resident in Australia and be eminent by reason of their scientific attainments and their researches in natural science' (Australian Academy of Science) and `Fellows shall be persons of the highest distinction in scholarship in the field of the humanities whose domicile at the time of their election is in Australia' (Australian Academy of the Humanities). Approximately ten per cent of fellows are female in both Academies. Both the named Academies follow standard Equal Employment Opportunity practice in advertising for office staff. The Academy of the Humanities has three office staff; one full-time and two part-time. All three are female. The Secretary is unpaid and male. The Australian Academy of Science has twenty office staff; two males who are employed full-time, and eighteen females of whom five hold permanent part-time positions.

(2) Both Academies operate under Royal Charter and according to By-Laws which govern membership which is by election by existing fellows. Amendments to the By-Laws require the assent of the Governor-General in Council. The only ground for election is conspicuous research excellence in the area of expertise covered by that Academy.

(3) The Academies derive their income from a number of sources: a Grant-in-Aid from the Commonwealth, subscriptions, donations and the sale of publications. The Grant-in-Aid payment is made to the Academies by the Government in recognition of the body of expertise which they represent and on which the Government can call as required.

(4) Both the named Academies, and the two others not included in the question, comply with national legislation aimed at equity and social justice. All office positions are freely available to all suitably qualified applicants, and election to membership of the Academies is on the sole criteria of achievement in research and contribution to knowledge in the Academy's area of interest.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 24 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the tour operator, the owner of Kapitan Khlebnikov, or any intermediary in connection with proposed voyages to Antarctica during November and December 1992 and January 1993, seek to satisfy all the requirements and conditions imposed by the Commonwealth, before advertising the voyages.
(2) Have all the requirements and conditions been met or will they be met.
(3) Has a permit been issued for the vessel Kapitan Khlebnikov to visit Heard Island.
(4) Have Quark Expeditions provided all requested details of the nature and status of contingency plans for marine pollution emergencies.

(5) If the requirements and conditions are not satisfied, or details of contingency plans for marine emergencies are not provided, will the Minister remove the risk of environmental damage to the Antarctic, Heard Island and Macquarie Island by preventing departure of the vessel from an Australian port and/or disassociate the venture from Australian Government involvement and support.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Quark Expeditions first contacted the Antarctic Division in relation to the proposed voyages to Antarctica by facsimile dated 22 January 1992. An advertisement for the proposed voyages appeared in the press on 21 January 1992.

(2) Quark Expeditions has advised the Antarctic Division that the terms and conditions prescribed by the Antarctic Treaty and the Protocol requirements and other specific guidelines laid down by the Commonwealth will be fully met and strictly observed. However, some aspects of the proposed voyages still require further resolution.
(3) No. Quark Expeditions has applied to the Antarctic Division for a permit for the vessel Kapitan Khlebnikov to visit Heard Island and this is presently being processed by the Division.

(4) Quark Expeditions has advised that they have determined from the shipowner that the Kapitan Khlebnikov does not have any particular contingency plans for marine pollution emergencies. The Antarctic Division has advised Quark Expeditions that contingency plans for vessels are a requirement of both the Madrid Protocol and the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships 1973 (MARPOL) and, while these have not yet entered into force, it has suggested that the organisation encourage the owners of the vessel to develop contingency plans as soon as possible. Quark Expeditions has also stated that the Kapitan Khlebnikov has a double hull of icebreaker strength and that no fuel is carried next to the hull.
The Australian Maritime Safety Authority is seeking copies of international ship safety and pollution control certificates for the Kapitan Khlebnikov.

(5) Permission for the Kapitan Khlebnikov to visit Macquarie Island is a matter for the Tasmanian Government. In relation to visits to Australia's Antarctic stations and Heard Island, Commonwealth agreement is subject to a number of requirements, including environmental and safety requirements. It should be noted that the Government is not involved with Quark Expeditions beyond considering its request for visits to Australian stations and Heard Island, and has not supported or endorsed the venture.
